content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Product received for free
												Nuclear Throne is an action packed roguelike developed by Vlambeer that takes place in the apocalyptic future. You find yourself playing as one of 12 mutants fighting to stay alive long enough to reach the fabled Nuclear Throne, a device that is said to be able to revert the world to what it once was. This game is sure to keep you hooked in a love/hate relationship with its frustrating but rewarding gameplay, many characters that offer a different style of playing each, variety of weapons (over 100 in total,) and seven playable areas with many other secret areas to discover.Pros:-Beautiful art drawn by Paul Veer-Music that captures the mood and environment perfectly by Jukio Kallio-Addicting and challenging gameplay-12 different characters that allow for a different gameplay experience every time.-Over 100 different weapons that are satisfying and fun to use. Ranging from a simple Revolver to a Double Minigun and a Super Plasma Cannon-A wide variety of enemies that are sure to test your worthiness of the Throne-Cooperative gameplay: local and a fantastic mod that allows you to play online with a friend developed by YellowAfterlifeCons:-The game is locked to 30FPS-It is also drawn at a 4:3 aspect ratio because it "prefers vertical movement" It doesn't, the developers dropped the ball on this one-Some aspects and enemies are a tad too challenging for a game that plays at 4:3-The developers have stated it will never go on sale. Even for its low price, sometimes I feel as if it isn't worth the price-Infrequent updates: The developers often delay updates for months, the most recent of which has been delayed 307 days since its announcement (as of Nov. 23, 2016)After all is said and done, I feel Nuclear Throne is an excellent game overall, but no game is without its flaws, especially this one; but I would certainly recommend it to anyone who enjoys a challenge.

number of helpful: 37 of 47 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								After playing a bit more of this, I can honestly say that this game is fun. It's a run-and-gun rpg bullet hell roguelike shoot-em-up from my own backyard (because Holland is about the size of a typical backyard). There are many aspects to making a game, and all of those (or at least most) have to be met in order for a game to be truly good. This game does just that. It takes every single one of my conditions for a good game and fills them in. Twice. Actually, I have two sets of conditions for the only two types of games that can ever be truly amazing: story-driven open world and hard-core skill & reflex fest. And it must also not be Call of Duty because that game ♥♥♥♥ing sucks balls. Anyway, this game falls into the second category, and let me explain what my criteria are and how it completely shreks the hell outta them. Unlike Call of Duty.Enemies. Any self-respecting game needs tons of varied enemies to keep things interesting and to make a natural transition to more difficult gameplay. Don't just add lvl. 44 to your opponent and give him more health and damage, make a new one! With different attack plans, weapons, health and speed. That's how you justify harder enemies, not by giving him a higer number. This game gets that, and every stage has it's own set of mortifying enemies that are designed especially to work on every nerve in your body. It's annoying to have to get to learn every opponent by dying from them first, but that's how it works. Nothing in life ever goes well on the first try. Except Call of Duty that stupid half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Ah that game is really getting on my nerves hrrrrrgghhh...Difficulty. In order for a game to actually be satisfying it has to be hard. Have you ever felt proud after you have eaten a banana? No? Wanna know why not? Because even a monkey could do it. It's not hard, it's not special, anyone could do it. Just like beating Call of Duty. It's not rewarding to do something anyone could do, it's only rewarding when you put time and effort into it. When you have thought about that glorious moment of opening a banana every second for the past 4 months of pure struggling. When you have longed for the taste of a banana for all that time. That's when eating a banana feels good, and that's what REAL men go for. And that struggle is exactly what makes Nuclear Throne rewarding to loop. That's right, Nuclear Throne is in fact unbeatable, for it has no end.Weapons. Preferrably of varied rarerity. A good selection of guns, of which at least a few hard to get, makes any game more enjoyable. It is necessary in games that are intended for replay, since playing the same game over and over again requires at least some aspect of variety. Hence the perks, random levels and tons of weapons. It's all there to keep you, the paying consumer, indulged in the game so that you'll tell your friends how cool it is and they would buy it too. Variety is the spice of life, they say, and I think the best example of that is having lots of guns in a run-and-gun rpg bullet hell roguelike shoot-em-up type of game.A good game also requires some type of milestones to help players remember that they ARE making progress! In this game that is done with levels and bosses. Anytime you beat one, you will know again that you have become better, encouraging you to play some more (and tell your friends about it)!Furthermore, under no circumstance should a good game ever be Call of Duty. Fortunately, this game is in fact NOT Call of Duty, and therefore meets this condition.I would have a few more criteria, but I think those speak for themselves. Anyway, there you have it, a great game and the reasons why! I do encourage you to go out and buy this game, even though it is not finished yet. It is already immense fun and more than worth your while and money.

number of helpful: 26 of 29 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Would I recommend this game? Absolutely, if you would like a shooter game that has a lot of character and a lot of replayability. It has a lot of playable characters that can drastically alter how you play, and tons of weapons you can try, a lot of which are fun.However that recommendation comes with some caveats, as this is not an entirely fair or skill-based game. It's better at it than say, Binding of Isaac, but you are still going to suffer a lot of cheap deaths. Things exploding on you, guys charging in from off-screen, or just getting bad weapons or bad spawns (I'm aware Hammerhead is a thing, but I feel if you need a specific perk to show up to counteract a situation, that's still a flaw even if there's a fix for it - plus there are still enemies that don't really much about what cover you have). The game's not entirely balanced, either. There's weapons you wouldn't want to use, like the Toxic weapons, which are impractical and can hurt you since there's no way to negate toxic damage, or the Screwdriver, by far the worst melee weapon in the game which is only useful for one secret; seeing it drop after you can get that secret feels like a joke on you. It also feels like there's a big disparity in mutations, as well, since there are ones like Boiling Veins, which protects you from dying to explosions (and this game has a LOT of explosions), and Strong Spirit, which gives you a mulligan from death once per stage; really practical things as you go through the game. Then there's say, Lucky Shot, which can give you ammo of a random type when you kill an enemy - except that you usually won't find yourself switching weapons all that often, and the game tends to naturally drop ammo for stuff you don't have anyway. Or Extra Feet, which makes you faster (something one of the character does already), and negates the effect of terrain...but there are only instances of that in two areas, one of which is only a single stage long. I understand this is meant to encourage different builds, but there's a good reason some of these are considered 'core' mutations and others aren't.I should say this isn't the case for the characters, though, as every one of them feels distinct and appeals to a different kind of player. You want to be good on Ammo, pick Fish. You want to be careful, Crystal or Eyes. Pure damage? Steroids or YV. Want the game to abuse you like a dog? Go Melting.I don't know how many of the reviews bring this up, but I also love the game's sound. Pretty much every enemy has a bunch of unique soundbytes for attacks they use, which is helpful for reacting, as well as when they die, which is useful for knowing when you've killed something offscreen (and is also immensely satisfying for several foes - looking at you, Lil' Hunter). This isn't always foolproof though, as sometimes a bunch of sounds can happen at the same time. I hope I haven't implied I dislike the game by criticizing it, because if I genuinely didn't like it I wouldn't have played as long as I have. It's a great game. But playing it is pretty much tough love, and you'll need to keep that in mind a lot.

number of helpful: 23 of 26 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Don't let yourself get fooled by the bright blue thumb up, this game is/was a wild train-ride which ended in a crash. Pun intended.(If U99/U100 fixes♥♥♥♥♥♥ Ill update this review.)>>Emotional backstory, if you wanna read the review, scroll down.<<You put a certain level of trust in a dev when you buy an early access game, and honestly, I thought that trust I put into Nuclear Throne and Vlambeer was well put with what they did. They communicated with the community, they did weekly dev streams and weekly updates. You really felt like you were part of the development. I have never seen any other devs do the entire early access thing this good, and to this date I hope for it to eventually be the standard.Nearing the end of 2015, it all started to get downhill. Several issues addressed by a lot of players back then were said to be fixed "in the polishing phase" - right now, we had the "feature and content phase" - so balance, bugs, crashes etc. were to be fixed by then. The problem was that the so called "polishing phase" never really came alongside of other expectations raised by the dev, like full-seeding-support, or other things, like balance-overhauls of areas and other things. There was an insane amount of potential for Nuclear Throne, and the community reported and helped the devs more than enough to make the fullest out of that potential.Not saying they didn't do anything, though,  there was a certain level of polish done, some bugs were fixed, some details like ravens leaving feathers added. Major crashes, some people literally being unable to play the game and other bugs though? Completely ignored. I didn't mind back then, since the game was in early access - and its completely acceptable for a game in early access to have crashes and bugs, since you know.An early access game can have bugs and crashes, since its unfinished. A released game however says that the game is done - little bugs and crashes are supposed to be there.So, around the end of 2015, the devs further and further pushed to release, constantly threw the sentence "we are almost done guys!" - which was followed by an insane amount of negativity by the community. Understandably, since, as I already said, there were tons of bugs, crashes and balance issues still to be fixed. No way they'll release the game like that - that's atleast what I thought, since I still trusted Vlambeer in their decision.Until the shocking date of the 5th December - around 5 months have passed since the release. Remember that number, it'll become relevant later. That is when they announced the release of the game for both the PC and consoles, and that is when people started loosing their♥♥♥♥♥♥ The extremely negative stigma and feeling of disappointment really got onto some people, understandably, since the game is in a broken state."uhh buddy, ya sure you didn't mean "back then" ? - I mean, 5 months have passed, s-surely they fi - "Nope. Some people still cant play the game, several people still crash, and people still get a frozen screen.This is not me complaining about the broken balance of the game (which you have lots of) - but me complaining about a game said to be "released" to have a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of bugs and crashes. I'm not overreacting either, you have lots of jokesters saying "B-but, it isnt that bad!" - It is that bad - Hell, one of the main reasons I stopped doing Dailies is because 30% of my daily runs end in a freeze, followed up with a death screen.And don't let me get started on the console version of the game, that version has its own set of issues like the player not being able to select their starting weapon, crown or skin - btw, these people have not even received both of the tiny updates which fixed maybe 5% of the issues available - reminder, 5 months have passed.--- And the ride is still going for both the PC Version and the console version. Both versions are still screwed, and while the changelog of Update 99 looks pretty, it's already sad that it takes over 5 months to fix insane issues.I'll put it like STAR_, an ex-Nuclear Throne Streamer said it when he streamed the game after a long pause : "Game was more stable and better 3 months ago."------------------------------Now, the game ; Let's talk about the game, the main thing you are here I'll assume.Pros: - Fluid Controls and Game-feel.- Wide selection of Weapons.- Lots of Characters and combinations to try out.- Dailies and Weeklies (Runs where everyone has the "same Seed" (<- Not really since Seeds are broken.) which end up with your score (Right now : Kills.) being submitted to a leaderboard and www.thronebutt.com )  add extra replayability and competition which encourages improvement.- Sound effects are tastier than Guy Fieri's hottest hits.Neutral:- Mediocre amount of perks upon leveling up + them not being really balanced leaves up for a very limited amount of viable perks, thus runs end up feeling the same.- Pixel art tastes differently in everyone's mouth, while I like it most of it, I wouldnt call it amazing.- Same goes for the Music. It's good if you'd ask me, but nothing too amazing.- It's a difficult game. If you are a soft-bean which wants to be spoonfed, this isn't the game for you. Can and will likely get insanely frustrating.- While Roguelike elements are there, it is not enough to make the game not feel repetitive for most at the end.- Crowns (Gameplay modifiers) are the definition of missed potential.Negative: - 30 FPS.- No widescreen Support.- Several Bugs and crashes which have been reported several times are still not fixed. Some Features even unfinished.- Late-game and perk-balance is far from a good state.** This♥♥♥♥♥♥will have a lot of Spoilers about late-game, so if you wanna explore that yourself, lemme sum it up : Expect terrible balance of both enemies and weapons.I don't know what happened to the idea of Loops, I suppose it was rushed like the entire game was. Another thing pushed back to "we'll do that later" - only to be ended up half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ The main idea back then was "Less-enemies, less randomness, more Elites! The Elites are the thing making the Loops hard, har har!" - however that transformed into "We can't be bothered to make more Elite enemies which is why we made 6 and then just added enemies out of secret areas and left the rest pretty much as it is"The Quality of the Elite enemies we got sunk and sunk until we got nothing, too. It first started with Elite IDPD, which were cool with their own unique sprites and attacks, but however came with frustrating Insta-kills, because apparently you can only make something hard if it instantly kills you. Anyways, from these, we went to Elite-Aligators, which also instantly killed the player upon being shot, and then we went to literally two deviantart-reskins, one of them being insanely weak. That's it. Some Areas literally don't have any Elite enemies.Oh, Vans too. Sometimes unavoidable, even."But it's a single player game, why should balance matter in that?"Because it isn't a single player game. With the addition of online-leaderboards, the player is now going for "the best" - which ended up with a stale Daily meta of Melee, SPC, and CoB. Maybe 15% of the Weapons in the game are viable late-game with CoB. Instead of being about "who is better at the game?" - Dailies are now "Who is better at the modified game?"Oh right, Perks. We have an insanely limited amount of Perks, or called, Mutations, which are also horribly balanced. There is a certain "elite 10" of mutations which are practically objectively better than the rest, the usual stale meta stuff which is part of why the game might get boring quickly and runs feel the same. This is a case where quantity and quality is low.TL:DR: Good game with huge issues which might ruin it for some.

												So far, Nuclear Throne is the greatest Rogue-Like game ever made. The best thing about this game is the gameplay. Games are supposed to be extremely fun because of their gameplay not graphics. Nuclear Throne is a great example of that. Its gameplay is really smooth and easy to follow with, which the Binding of Isaac did not have. The controls are absolutely brilliant and made me feel like I am in complete control of my movements and weapons. The number of guns to choose is absolute freakin' insane! There are a lot of characters to choose from with different perks which provide a lot of insane replayability value. Oh and man... The explosions. The explosions are so satisfying.This is one of the perfect examples of how Early Access games should be handled. The devs worked really hard and updated the game often and listened to the community. Huge props to the devs. Well done. Overall, the game is a masterpiece for its gameplay and is absolutely addicting. I am a harsh reviewer and I decided to give this game a 9.5 out of 10 which will place this game at 6th place into my "Steam HALL of FAME" list where only 15 games have obtained at least a 9 or greater so far. I have been gaming on Steam for 7 years and that's a big deal. Buy this game. You won't be disappointed.9.5 out of 10

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne feels really good to play. Instant, immediate fun. Pick a character, move, shoot, pick up new weapons, shoot again.I am usually not fond of top-down shooters, but Vlambeer completely nailed it. The feedback of the weapons is great (it is even possible to reflect shots). It is so much a pleasure to play that dying and trying again in the randomly-generated levels does not feel frustrating. Except for a few specific ways to be killed, like flames from some traps, and taking multiple hits from the same source because of a lack of 'invulnerability frames' after the first hit.Another great thing is that progress through the levels is quite fast, so deaths are not as disheartening as in other games. I don't even care about permadeath and reaching the end: I just want to shoot things and get as far as I can until I die. And try again, because I am having fun. There are official daily runs: a common level for everyone, refreshed each day, that can only be tried once. As often, players are ranked daily on leaderboards. This feature gives me a great incentive to play Nuclear Throne each day for at least a quick run (sometimes, really really quick, like less than a minute - yeah this game is not a walk in the park). Unlike The Binding of Isaac, in which I know that a single run can last for a long time and thus I am less inclined to launch it on a whim.Each character has different and original special skills that allow for a different gameplay, from minor variations to major differences. There is variety in the enemies and their way to attack, however since there are no alternate levels (there are many secret levels though), playing through the same starting area again and again can get a bit too familiar. The art is cute and the music is perfectly adequate. Only gripe here is that the framerate is locked to 30. An instant favorite to me.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												Nuclear Throne is a real Vlambeer gem. There's alot of detail found in every hole and around every dark corner this game consists of. After playing for a while, the game boils down to a science, things you do seem to just slot in to place with the game's agenda and it becomes almost systematic. The game is difficult, that's more than true, but you'll achieve such a rush in looping it compensates for the hardship you'll face trying to beat the Nuclear Throne for the first time. Also, you can definately feel the difference between the mutants you play as, each one has their own back-stories and reasons why they've wound up in this nightmare, and each of them want victory for different reasons, release, redemption, a show of weapon-weilding potency or the very taste of blood. Nuclear Throne's soundtrack is epic, it's as fast paced as the gameplay, it brilliantly suits this game and is one of my favourite OSTs out there. The assortment of guns, the bosses, the varied enemies and the unpredictability & variation are just some of the reasons Nuclear Throne is fantastic, it's a very worth-while price too, if you're considering it, watch the plethora of videos of the game on YouTube to get more of an understanding and a feel for it, but I, personally, would definately recommend picking it up.

Early Access Review
								This might be the best top-down shooter I have played for a long time. The controls are so tight it's practically claustrophobic. Death - and thus the end of your run - is a constant nemesis, but it is always fair. You get a bit greedy for that XP or ammo or health, push out a bit too far and you are toast; your fault, pal.It boasts a huge variety of playable characters and "mutations" (bonuses that affect your character) so that each run feels suitably different and rewarding. Combine this with a fantastic soundtrack and appealingly chunky pixel art style and you have a real winner.Even though it is still in Early Access, it's basically finished now, so dip in! Hugely recommeded.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												These are a few things to expect in this game, whether or not they throw you off or persuade you further to play decides whether or not this game is for you: This game is hard, no matter which way you spin it, but has the benefits of having a character for numerous play styles to give you more than 1 way to go at it. While RNG plays a part in it in terms of weapon drops and perks you can choose with each level, slow progression should be enough proof that these aren't the only factors. The first boss will kick your♥♥♥♥♥when you begin, and you'll be laughing him off after an hour or so. 80% of deaths will be your fault and your fault alone, 20% will be cheap deaths due to either where you spawned on the map, or the map itself. As of writing this review, the 3 top guides to help you can be pretty much summed up with "get gud", the community claiming most complaints about the game being due to a lack of skill. This game would definitely be for people who tanked their way through Binding of Isaac for days on end, and in a vague sense, Dark Souls aswell...its that frustrating, head-banging pleasure you get from succeeding after the 148th try.To sum it up, this game will taunt you endlessly as you play it, whether or not you're the type to quickly give up and play something actually fun, or if you're the type who is only driven to play it more, will decide on if this games for you.

number of helpful: 19 of 22 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												( Update 95)I seriously thought I'd never see the day Nuclear Throne came out of early access, but here we are after two years of constant weekly updates and support from the developers.I won't go into detail about how well they handled the early access system because that doesn't really determine the value of the finished game, but the devs are some of the best when it comes to talking to their community and being completely open about the development of Nuclear Throne, including regular streams that allows people to watch the devs do their thing. It's a wonderful example of how well early access can be used to create the best game possible, and I hope future titles learn from Vlambeers success.Anyways, the game as it stands now:ProsExtremely difficult, yet rewarding.12 (+2 secret) characters,all with unique playstyles and mechanics. Some are very basic to learn, while others are more suited for advanced players. Over 100 weapons. I felt like making the weapons aspect of this review larger because of how varied they are, but I'll just say this to sum it up: Super Bazooka. Daily and Weekly runs give the game a competitive aspect. The daily system is currently broken as of writing this review, however I'll update it when it is fixed. If the daily runs are the reason you may be wanting to buy NT, I'd wait for a while until it gets fixed.Quite possibly my favorite soundtrack of the year.Gorgeous artwork which really helps make the NT universe come to life. Yung Venuz Cons: There is currently a lot of bugs in the game. Some of these are very minor texture glitches while some completey render the game unplayable on some systems. Like I said above, the developers are very much aware of these and are working on fixes right now, but I might suggest waiting until the next update comes around. This is a very controversial subject in the NT community, but keep in mind that the game is capped at 30 FPS. In my honest opinion I find this to be completely okay, and I'm usually picky when it comes to FPS issues in games. But NT is designed around 30 fps and doesn't suffer from any of the usual issues.  There are some balancing issues when it comes to a secret aspect of the game after the final boss. The devs are aware of this however, and are gonna tone down some of the unfair aspects of it. Easily my game of the year, It's been a fantastic experience watching this game grow into one of the best rouge-likes of all time. My conclusion would be to wait until a future update, but if you have a need for a new rouge-like/lite, seriously don't hesistate in buying this. 200 hours in and I'm still having a blast killing various monsters with super flak cannons.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
TL;DR: FAST, DIFFICULT AND FUN AS HELL SHOOTER WITH A LOT OF UNLOCKS AND SECRETS. BUY IT IT'S AMAZINGOh boy where do I start with this game?Let me tell you, this game is HARDCORE. You know Dark Souls? You play Dark Souls to relax after playing Nuclear Throne, that's how hardcore it is. You start out playing Nuclear Throne and you're like "yeah, whatever, some shooter or somethin', I guess this is a little fun". But then you die. Over and over again you die, and start getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off at how bad you are at this, and force yourself to get better. As you progress, you start noticing that this little harmless shooter was not as shallow as it first seemed. It it DEEP, it has SO MANY THINGS in it. Guns, enemies, maps, bosses, secret little things to do and unlock that make you go into a secret-seeking frenzy. You think you're done when, after countless hours, you beat the final boss? Psh, you haven't seen ANYTHING yet. This is the kind of game that you have to experience for yourself, so I'm not going to spoil anything. I only recommend that you try playing this along with friends if you're not into searching for secrets on the internet, they might find something you overlooked and vice-versa. Now, for the Pros and Cons section of this review:THE GOOD: Fast, fun and addicting gameplay; Huge variety of weapons; Level-ups and upgrades that are actually meaningful and useful; Plenty of characters with different and unique abilities to choose from;  Unique theme with characters that grow on you despite speaking their own bizarre language; A bunch of sometimes extremely difficult to find secrets; Unlocks that challenge you in innovative ways to improve your playstyle; Runs go by quickly and allow for fast gameplays during breaks at work, school, or anything else; A ton of other stuff and tiny amazing details that you notice as you play.THE BAD: Certain deaths feel very unfair and frustrating; Sometimes, as with any game of the genre, RNG lets you down; The difficulty in gameplay and in uncovering some secrets may push certain people away before they can truly enjoy the experience.THE VERDICT:This game is absolute must-play. If, after giving it a real and long try, you end up not liking it, so be it. Chances are, though, if you're a fan of roguelikes, shooters or just FUN GAMES, you'll most likely love this one. Its price may seem a little too high from someone who hasn't played it yet, as it seems like any other indie shooter, but the level of detail and content in this game way surpasses that price-point. Not to mention the countless hours you'll spend playing (and dying on) this game. Buy it, try it and, hopefully, love it.

								YES. I just love the game. The game runs smoothly even on my trash computer, and gameplay is exciting and never lets up. There's something for eveyone. Daily and weekly runs allow for competive play, and for the casuals, doing a bunch of regular runs is really fun. And then play it.(not really much point in buying it if you don't play it)

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								A punishing roguelike shooter with a surprising amount of nuanced gameplay. You play as one of several mutants in a post-apocalyptic setting. Your goal is to fight through throngs of enemies until you reach the Nuclear Throne. Along the way, you'll pick up different weapons and XP in the form of radiation. Each level you earn, you can choose a new mutation that helps you progress through the game.It sounds simple enough, and the basic jist of gameplay is. If you shoot things and don't get hit, you win. That's much easier said than done, though, especially as you spawn into levels randomly--something surrounded by enemies. Many times you'll have to go in guns blazing and run for cover. Others you'll weave in and out of bullet sprays while popping off a few well-aimed shots of your own. It's challenging and engaging, even in level 1-1. And that's a good thing, because you'll find yourself back there a lot.I thought this game would frustrate me, but so far I've had a smile on my face every time I've died. It's such a fun game that the only thing keeping me from hitting R to do a quick restart is other commitments.If roguelikes are your thing and you're a fan of punishing games, give it a whirl. Even though it's EA, it's extremely polished thus far and the develop updates it frequently.

number of helpful: 54 of 86 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Nuclear Throne is a fun and frantic top-down shooter rogue-lite in which you must defeat the Nuclear Throne with any of its interesting characters and multitude of weapons however it's rife with game ending problems at the moment.Pros + Frantic top-down action shooter rogue-lite.+ Multiple characters each with a unique active ability and ultra-mutations. If one doesn't fit your play style, simply choose another.+ Fun mutation system, sometimes you get ones you don't want but have to make it work.+ Interesting to infuriating enemies (I'm looking at you scorpions, rats, flame traps and green ooze exploder).+ Multitude of weaponry, some good, some bad, some great and some awful.+ Daily and Weekly Challenges ideas are great.+ Crown system for run manipulation.Cons - The game is prone to the occasional crash.- Still has a lot of bugs that should've been fixed before release, but alas the devs had to honour a contractual agreement on PSX and it would've seemed strange that it released on platform and not the other I guess.- Base weapon RNG is just terrible. The frequency at which you get duplicate weapons is way too high (but then again it's random).- Level generation leaves A LOT to be desired. Sometimes it's good and other times you get swarmed with no way out. The player should always spawn in a safe location and not right next to enemies as it currently does as this often leads to panic and death.- Some boss fights rely on your initial spawn namely Raven\Assassin + Sniper infested Big Dog fight and Tank + Snow Bot\Yeti Lil' Hunter fight.- Most Crowns seem rather pointless or worthless as they make your run worse with no added benefits.- The Daily Challenge is not really fair or balanced as players can choose whichever character to play as and certain characters are just better overall. Secret levels, big weapons chest and leveling right before a level has a tendency of changing the seed resulting in a modified level generation. Crowns especially Crown of Blood can have an unfair advantage on score (but this is more like Ghosting in Spelunky so I'm not too peeved about it, if you're good enough to do it then do it).- Speaking of Daily and Weekly Challenges, their leader boards have been broken since release. I know the devs are working on it but it should've been ready at launch.- Hard Mode is just terrible and not fun. The game basically starts on Loop 1, 1-1 and the player is given a big weapons chest at the start which contains 'beginning tier' weapons to deal with  swarms of enemies. I get that Hard Mode was put in as a joke but that is most certainly not how you do hard mode.Irritations - Each character starts off with the same gear, a pistol except Chicken and Rogue. Even though you can unlock golden weapons to start off with, I'd have liked if each character had a different base starting weapon.- Enemies know your position as you spawn even without line of sight and often shoot at you from off-screen.- Enemy AI is too inconsistent at times; Bandits will often look at you and shoot backwards or vice-versa. Yeti bots can be stuck in their charge state for a very long time often gliding across the levels. Snow dogs can be stuck in their shoot pattern for far too long. IDPD inspectors often shoot their shots at you even though you are far beyond thier reach.- The game is unbalanced as a result of some changes made during the Early Access phase and too often the difficulty of situations feel cheap as it was beyond the player's control.- Looping is a mess; prepared to be swarmed by flies, scorpions, snipers and\or assassins unless you have a powerful weapon or skill.- I feel the game relies too heavily on RNG this is seen clearly with the seed generation and weapon drops the for Daily and Weekly Challenges.- Tiered weapon distribution needs some work still. At 'late game' pre-loop, you shouldn't even be given 'beginning tier' weapons any more or rather they should drop less in my opinion.- You tell me to avoid weapons chests and when I do you give me 2 wrenches and a low tier bullet weapon mid game. What kind of rubbish is that?- Secret levels aren't really interesting to be honest. I wish there were unique weapons you could only attain on those levels like how it was done in Spelunky.- It makes no sense to me why the player is the only one affected by Flame Trap in the Wasteland and Spider Webs in the Caves. Enemies should not be able to walk or run full speed on the webs except for the spiders and crystals.- I wish the scoring system used for the Daily\Weekly Challenge Leader board rankings relied on something more than just kills, something like a point system for instance.* Points based on enemy types (1pts - Maggot, 3pts - Big Maggot, 5pts - Bandit, 15pts - Scorpion, 30pts - Golden Scorpion etc.)* 1.0		- Loop 0 multiplier (increments by 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 2.0 etc.)* 100pts	- Per level, affected by the Loop Multiplier* 250pts	- Secret levels (multiples of 250)* 500pts	- Defeating bosses (multiples of 500)* 750pts	- Crown raid + taking crowns* 1000pts	- IDPD HQ raidVerdict  Nuclear Throne is an extremely enjoyable and frantic rogue-lite which requires your utmost attention as any wrong slip will result in your death. Sometimes you get a crap seed where you get murdered instantly, don't get the right mutations or weapons and other times you get all the right mutations and weapons and go on a murderous rampage. That feeling is exhilarating. However it was released with various bugs that should've been fixed while in Early Access and it unfortunately represents the first strike against Vlambeer's perfect or near perfect record. So can I recommend you buy this game, sadly no, not with all the issues currently surrounding it which is a shame as the game is really enjoyable. However, if you can overlook the Cons and Irritations and understand that you're purchasing an unfinished game then by all means go for it, otherwise it's best to wait a while until the bugs\issues are fixed.- Review Update: (2016-02-22 Update 98) -VerdictNuclear Throne is an extremely enjoyable and frantic rogue-lite which requires your utmost attention as any wrong slip will result in your death. Sometimes you get a crap seed where you get murdered instantly, don't get the right mutations or weapons and other times you get all the right mutations and weapons and go on a murderous rampage. That feeling is exhilarating. Although it was released in a broken manner, it seems Vlambeer was hard at work to fix all\most of what was broken and I'm happy to sasy that I'm glad they did.So can I recommend you buy this game now after Update 98, sadly still no. Don't get me wrong Update 98 fixed some things like the Daily\Weekly Challenges and some other issues but the game is still buggy and crashes from time to time for no reason.

												EARLY ACCESS IS OVER !!!!! WAAAAAT YESSSS"more serious review on bottom"Nulcear throne is a very fast paced, bullet hell, Rogue-like action game thats brings a whole new meaning to the word " Difficult " I am completely satisfied by the game's early access adventure they came a long way from the beginning and all the updates we have now is more reasons to support this game.I still remember when I first got this game, had a lot of bugs so much missing stuff, but now ? SECRET levels, improved characters and improved art and improved everything You choose from 12 characters "That you can unlock as you progress in the game"and fight hordes and hordes of monsters with a HUGE Selection of weapons, "Seriously check the wiki DAMN"Each stage has 3 levels , goes like , 1-1 , 1-2, 1-3 ..etc and every 3 stages theres a "dark" one which sort of reminds me of the 2nd level in mario sort of I don't know I'm weird.Each character has its own passive and active abilities, making each one different from the other.You can carry 2 weapons at a time, switching between them for the ultimate hell shooter action.There are several boss fights in the game which introduces even more fun that it already gives, after beating the final level you can end the game for a story or do loops *cough*mario*cough" That goes on until you die, however loops are INSANE, you get an extra special abilities to pick from and the monsters are ... holy S***.The game has its own secrets, secret levels and easter eggs/reference whatever you'd call it and Im hoping they'd add more because its so good.Trust me when I say the game is hard its HARD but you'd get used to how fast it is, you'd get a bit frustrated at first on how suddenly BOOM you died WTF ? but then you'd get a clue on what to do and how to do it properly and you can follow some steam guides they're helpful.ACHIEVEMENTS ! The game didn't have this at first so I got really excited when they got finally implemented, although the achievements are not as much as you'd hope but they're HELLAhard to get.The soundtrack in the game is so good, this retro feel it gives me I love it. All the sound effects all the levels and their designs and characters are outstanding I cannot find the proper words to describe it so i'll make up a word "AWESOMARITYFEEEK" ...that didn't go well.You got daily challenges, you got weekly challenges, you got to do certain things to unlock other characters, you'll just keep killing monsters along the way as a way of life.Some people would get shot off by the fact that this game is locked on 30fps but it can never be fixed and devs admitted it was a "Poor developing choice" but thats ok since after 1 hour of the game you'll forget all that and get sucked into this endless wormhole of AWESOMEIRTYFEEEK TLDR One of the best twin-stick shooters I played "after boi", the difficulty and the content this game provides is insane10/10 the best early access game I backed.

Early Access Review
 Nuclear Throne Review  ''One of the best indie games currently available on steam.''  Summary: In a world where indie games are becoming an important part of the video game industry, it is hard to find a worthwhile indie gem which gives you a bang for your buck. Search no more. If you are a fan of shooting games, rogue-like games, 2d games or bloody good games, then Vlambeers' Nuclear Throne is the game you need in your library. This top-down shooter is perfectly designed and suitable for alot of type of players. The hard, solid gameplay aswell as the endless replayability of this title will let you stack hours upon hours of fun. On a more personal note, this game is one of my favorites of all time. It is truly unbelievable.. The Good's and The Bad's  The goods  Incredible replayability A varied and enjoyable roster of characters Tons of crazy guns Weekly updates Alot of ennemies A huge number of secrets Action-packed fun Local Co-op Very neat design The bads  Some may find it a little too hard Score and closing line  9.5: Outstanding.  ''Vlambeers delivers an ambitious indie game that sets a new standard in gaming.''

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												This, ladies and gents, is the most fun I've had with a twin-stick permadeath shooter since The Binding of Isaac. With a passionate community and a development team that went above and beyond to make this game into something truly wonderful with said community, this game is certainly the full package.  Everything from the music to the art has wonderful grit and polish, the setting of a hopeless post-apocalyptic wasteland never feeling so vibrant and varied. The controls are smoother than a babe's backside, the design is solid, and the pace frenetic. This is one of those games where a run could last anywhere from five seconds to forty five minutes, but every time the first thought that comes up when the death screen is encountered is, "Let's have another go". Nuclear Throne is as good as it gets for the marriage of well-designed weapons, varied characters, and a hard-as-nails bullet hell atmosphere that will hand you your own♥♥♥♥♥time and time again and leave you begging for more.

												Nuclear Throne it's the perfect blend between a Shoot 'em Up Bullet Hell, a Roguelike Top Down Shooter with some spice of RPG, featured bugs and an amazing soundtrack that will follow along with you and your journey of becoming the most badass ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the block.The game itself is fast paced, but easy AND FUN to master, you have plenty of characters (Mutants) with their own passive and active abilities, from a blindfolded chicken with slowmo (since Update #76 Chicken now throws weapons and no longer has slowmo) and an anabolics-infused scientist that can dual wield to a fish that can roll, yes, that's right, Fish can roll. You level up by getting Radiation that is dropped from enemies and found in canisters around the levels, everytime you level up, you will be able to choose a power up (Mutation) when you finish a level. You start with a single weapon but can have 2 at any given time from over the 100 that the game has, they are found in chests and sometimes dropped by enemies and can be switched anytime, find your favourite combinations of Mutants, Mutations and Weapons and kill everything. Have fun.Update #60 Edit: Now it actually has over 100 guns.2016 Update: Many loops later this game is giving me PTSD, play at your own risk.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
Update Since this review I've been hired to work for the company which made this game as a freelancer. This review was written way before I even thought of that, and I still do think that this is a great game, but I am obviously biased now and you should read another review if that bothers you. I haven't changed the original review, so here it is.Nuclear Throne is at the same time easy to pick up and detailed enough that you'll spend dozens of hours looking for various tricks, trying out different strategies, weapon matches, finding secret areas, and the most important thing - shooting mutants and rebels and fighting off the interdimensional police which is always on your tail. As a rougelike, it's not for the faint of heart - levels, the amount of enemies, weapons and mutations you get are always random and will differ each time you boot up the game. This allows you to replay the game as much as you like and it's always going to be just as great as the first time.There's no detailed unlock systems which force you to invest hundreds of hours into the game to get the full experience. Almost all characters and all weapons will be available after your first playthrough. Pick up someone with the pleasant name and go. Feel like having an all-out powerful run where you can blow up corpses of your enemies? Go ahead. Feel like casually strolling through the wasteland with your allies? Go ahead. Feel like having a frantic experience where the game randomly throws enemies at you when it feels like it? Go ahead.From plasma cannons to heavy crossbows, from double miniguns to auto flame shotguns - this game has it all. Just saying the name of a weapon makes you imagine it and think how awesome it is. And when you finally get to find them in game, pick them up and use them, it's going to be just as awesome and just as chaotic as you imagined. As this game is in early access, new weapons are being added all the time, and when you read something like "Added a Flame Cannon" in the update notes, you can't help but smile and think to yourself - yes, that's exactly the amount of chaos I want to cause next time I open up this game.You WILL die. You will die a lot. You will die in the most fair and the most unfair ways possible. But one thing is for sure. Each death, no matter how infuriating, will always teach you something. And in the end, each death makes you a better player. In a matter of hours, you will be pulling off professional dodging maneuvers, carefully picking mutations to build your character for the strategy you envisioned and the weapons you have, and before you know it, it will be 3am and you will be saying "just one more run".As this game is in early access, it's bound to change and I hope that it proceeds in the direction it's heading. If you're in doubt whether you're going to get your money's worth - yes, you will. You will get much more than that. Once it's out of early access, I have no doubts that this game will be one of the best games released for that year. I honestly recommend you pick the game up and give it a shot.

												Nuclear Throne is an interesting game to tackle, basically if you want the most short and dumbed down version of the review: It's a top-down roguelike shooter you both love and hate.This game features 12 characters, each one with custom passives, actives, pros and cons, And the goal of the game is to reach the Nuclear Throne, On the way to sit thy throne you'll find many weapons, and you'll level up to select upgrades, The game feels wonderful to play with smooth controls, and nice music and crunchy sound effects, It does great at capturing that wonderful arcade feel.In this game however, don't expect to beat it in your first few attempts, It's hard, REALLY HARD,But it's so worth it.If online co-op is your thing there's a mod which adds that, which is also wonderful.This is probably like 90% biased so take this with a grain of salt but i love the game, and i can easily reccommend it.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												48 hours. That's how long it took me to finally sit on the 'Nuclear Throne'. However my winning run was only 14 minutes. Then I find out the game loops!? And has even MORE stuff after looping?! This game is truly the 'Tales of Maj'Eyal' for action rougelikes. Lot's of content, endless replayability, randomized levels, and some real difficulty to keep you busy for a long time.TL;DR+ Huge replayability+ Lot's of content+ Good Difficulty+ Easy to pickup or put down- Screen can get a little crazy- Exploding cars- Lil' Hunter (may he rot in Nuclear Hell!)GAMEPLAYThis game is a 2D rougelike. For those of you who don't know what rougelike means, it is a game genre that is characterized by you dying often... But you die often in plenty of other games too... So what's the difference? Well, a rougelike seems to intend that you die multiple times, and not just to learn from your mistakes (though you do), but to set points of progress that you must better yourself by. Each death you say to yourself, "I can do better than that" and you can... It just might take some practice. Even if you've only got 15 minutes to play you'll be getting better every time.Anyways, the game has multiple characters for you to play as through a randomly generated set of levels in 7 different areas. You collect 'rads' from fallen enemies that are used to upgrade your character with different abilities called 'mutations'. Each character fits different playstyles and strategies. For example: The 'Eyes' character has telekinetic abilities that can push away enemy projectiles while pulling in the enemies themselves. This suits them for melee oriented combat. The 'Fish' character can quickly roll in the direction of the mouse, allowing for easier dodging. Additionally the 'Fish' receives more ammo from pickups than the other characters. This suits them for running around the map dodging enemies while shooting like crazy.Not much in the game can truly be considered unfair when you think about it, aside from cars that explode and kill you right before you win the level... And a crazy flying blue-dude that can blow-up right on top of you immediately after he appears.The game encourages developing your skills on the different characters and mastering the many weapons to be found. If you're a good learner, it will quickly become a very enjoyable experience. If your a boulder-brained, doltish, stick-in-the-mud, you probably won't find much virtue in the learning process.STORYThe game itself doesn't really disclose any thing story-wise besides a wordless cutscene or two. However, the wiki for the game does have an interesting bit of lore to educate you on the world behind the bullets and explosions.GRAPHICSThe graphics are pixely and that fits the game just fine if you ask me. However, the crazy explosions, flames, smoke, and other eye candy can make it difficult to see the screen at times. Other than that, solid.CONCLUSIONI would definently recommend this game to anyone looking for some fun. It has been loaded with all sorts of interesting mechanics and unlockables that will keep you playing long after you thought you finally 'beat it'. Also, the price is pretty fair. Considering that I've spent alot more time playing this than I have other games that cost twice as much.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
Early Access Review
 REVIEW	Nuclear Throne is a roguelike, bullet hell shooter, with some RPG elements, however one could probably deduce that from the description. Vlambeer’s previous efforts to deliver a high-score based shooter, have failed to deliver on genuine replay value, and one could be done with them mere hours after purchase. Nuclear Throne is NOT that. You will be occupied for a long time after the purchase of Nuclear Throne, and will have your knowledge of the game tested, due to ever changing subtleties in the gameplay, level design and even themes as you progress. Be expecting a captivating experience for hundreds of hours after purchase, I know I’m only getting started! The gameplay in Nuclear Throne is simple. Each character has a passive and active ability. These abilities keep one from sticking with a single character, and force one out of their comfort zone. This is helped by the fact that all the abilities are majorly balanced (except for the Chicken, which has recently been nerfed). I would call the gameplay a hybrid of Hotline Miami and The Binding of Isaac, however it is so much more. This is due to its immense gameplay depth. By this I mean, the game allows you to adapt the gameplay to your playstyle, and alter character’s unlockable abilities to synergies with one another, for example: A person could choose the “get more crates ability” along with the “Find more weapons ability” to have a greater likelihood of finding more guns, if that’s how he plays. Speaking of guns, the game has a wide selection of creative weaponry. These go from melee weapons, to hybrids of sniper rifles, shotguns and even fire. Even through the carnage of setting the whole screen ablaze with a flame shotgun, one can easily appreciate the game’s worthwhile arsenal. The difficulty pacing is very well handled, because at times I noticed the game was being as I wanted it to. If  The gameplay is made more enjoyable by the game’s extremely well designed aesthetics. The screen shakes like crazy, and enemies flash white and pause when hit, to give the game a punchier, more powerful feel. The pixel art style is good. Nothing of the art is so beautiful that it deserves commending, but it at least gets the job done well. Enemies all look good, and help make the “post fallout” theme really be in the core of the game at all times, always making you feel like the world around you is a desolated wasteland. My major complaint is that the size of the pixels, make it, sometimes, difficult to distinguish major pieces of information, like text, or even bullets. I still find it difficult to distinguish between a shotgun, and a pop gun. Musically the game is fantastic. All music has a theme that corresponds to the environment where it is found, and it sounds great! Psychedelic vocals play in the sewers, and rap plays in Y.V.s pimped-out mansion. The actual sound design for all the weapons is fine. It doesn’t strive to do anything special, and sticks to the similar sounds found in most retro-shooters.  FINAL THOUGHTS	 In the unlikely event that you have read this far (please let me know in the comments if you have ☺), I would like to talk about the amazing job that the developers are doing. The game is in the dreaded “early access” stage, however the game right now is basically complete. Developers are constantly adding new content to keep the game fresh, and its getting kind of ridiculous! I’ve never seen such a passion for expanding the community (which is terrific by the way), and for that I respect Vlambeer, despite their shortcomings in Luftrausers. I strongly recommend anybody interested in fun games purchases this game, because its well worth its price, even in early access, make no mistakes, this is one of the best retro shooters ever, and I definitely wont be refunding this *wink wink* SCORE	80/100A solid title, worthy of players with interests in any other genre, and content well worth the price. Just don't come in looking for a well developed multiplayer.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												Now I hear a lot of people saying Enter the Gungeon is supposed to be better than this game and Isaac. Enter the gungeon is 60 fps while this game is 30 fps. However there are two main reasons why I prefer this game more to Gungeon. First is that the game feels a lot more skill based than gungeon. Whenever I play gungeon, it feels like how you do on the first boss widely depends on the items you get on the first floor. If you have not such a good loadout, the first boss feels like it takes forever to destroy. And most of the time, the loadout you get in the beginning isn't so great. In this game, that's not really the case. Usually by the time you reach the first boss, you have a lot likely adequately equipped, in which you can fight the boss without it overstaying its welcome. As for enemies in this game, it also feels like while you can kill enemies easily, they can kill you easily too, so how long you really last in this game depends on your skill. The other reason I prefer this game to Gungeon, and this is a big one, is because IT HAS ONLINE CO-OP. Well, unofficially. You have to download a mod to get it to work, called "Nuclear throne together". Believe it or not, this mod does have a fair share of users active. And after playing it for around an hour, I have to say that it is one of the best co-op games I've ever played. Enter the Gungeon could have also greatly benefitted from co-op but sadly it's not available in that game. Not to say that Gungeon isn't a bad game. What gungeon has in itself is solid. But this game feels like you win more with skill, not with the gun you're holding, and really, if you don't mind 30 FPS, you're going to have a hell of a time with this game.  Also you have many characters with different playstyles, craploads of guns, probably around the same amount as gungeon, and online play. Seriously, why are you still reading this? Go out and buy this game!My score of this game (with co-op) = 9.0/10

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												Early in this game's development, it already was an extremely satisfying game to play. The impacts of your actions and the crunchy sound effects added together to make a wonderful top-down experience. It seemed like they already had the "game feel" nailed, and most of Early Access would be focusing on adding more content. And then each update came, week after week, and it continued to just feel better and better, and with more content to boot! Any aspiring game developer should spend a good amount of time studying how Vlambeer gets the feeling of their games just right. The gameplay is fine too. The weapon/character/enemy variety keeps the game interesting for potentially hundreds of hours. The Early Access period also led to some very well balanced generation as well. Each run through the game depends almost entirely on skill alone; it's not often that the game screws you or carries you like in The Binding of Isaac.Mind you, it's still a difficult game. One moment might be going pretty well until a momentary lapse in concentration puts you from full health to zero. Life is fragile in the wasteland and it takes a good amount of dedication to gain the experience to reliably make it through even the first few areas. But even once you get the hang of it, there's no real skill ceiling to the game. The difficulty past the throne will continuously ramp up to push you to your limit, and those late game situations mowing through massive waves of enemies really highlight the "game feel" that Vlambeer does so well. A high recommendation from me. Give it a shot if you're up to the challenge.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												The thing about rougelikes is that they make you feel like a complete moron. You find yourself tutting at yourself, ashamed of your own ineptitude. Nuclear Throne is no different. In fact it's probably harsher than average. And that's a very good thing.Maybe I'm just a noob. I think I am. I get massacred every time: on numerous ocassions an irradiated rat has knawed me to death. Cars have exploded from stray enemy rounds and sent me spiralling across the level. A crocodile with a shotgun once made me wish my father had never had that dirty glint in his eye looking at my mother. I mean, they're divorced now, and that whole experience was probably less rage inducing than Nuclear Throne.I may be a sadomasochist for this type of thing, but I keep going back. Each run, each easily avoided slaying, simply drives me on to discover more of the complex progression system. The depth of game's secrets, weapon management and characters are all of incredibly high standard. All lures in their own right.But I think the main reasons I love this game are its weird sense of humour and beautfiul graphics. Any game that has a mutated Fish rolling around fighting robot assassins, giant maggots and really angry turtles, all rendered in an eye-wateringly lovely arcade art style, has my support.Buy it. Die. Die again. Stop playing for two days. Be drawn back like a fly to a steaming turd. Die some more. Relish every second.'tis good.

Early Access Review
								'Procedural Death Labyrinth' is absolutely the best way to describe this game. Hours of procedurally generated hard-as-nails top down shooter fun. You'll die over and over and over, but the game doesn't get any less fun. Great music to back up the unique visual style which fits perfectly with the gameplay. Vlambeer have outdone themselves with this title and I am sure I will continue to enjoy the game for many hours to come, even if I never do get good enough to reach the throne.Steam needs more top down shooters!

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												I suck hardcore at this game but I'm going to review it anyway (again). Basically it's a rouge-ish bullet hell game about a group of mutants who are on a journey to claim the nuclear throne, one of the most soul beating,♥♥♥♥♥♥kicking, rage inducing bosses ever (And it's not even really the final boss). You have a selection of 12 characters to play with, each with their strengths and weaknesses. It also includes a leveling up system with each level allowing you to choose from four powers, know as mutations. There are a multitude of stages with increasingly difficult enemies (But very few border the line of unfair). After a few levels a boss will spawn randomly from a wall or in the middle of the screen. These bosses range from: "Pfft that was a boss?" to "Ah♥♥♥♥♥♥I'm screwed, oh♥♥♥♥♥♥here he comes." I'd say it is very skill based and unforgiving, so if you are into that kind of thing in a game this will be right up your alley. I still have yet to master it but I still find the fun in it even if I suck. Also the devs seem interested in just making games and constantly updated the game till its full release, and there will most likely be content later. There are a couple of drawbacks however. Due to the games random nature, you can get a reaaaaaaally bad spawn where the boss spawns two feet from you or where you have minimum protection against a huge wave of fish (no joke). TL;DRPros: A good selection of charactersGood devsFun yet not boringly easyLots of secretsNice art and sound tracksA looping systemLOCAL Co-opCons: A couple of unfair bosses/enemiesRNG spawns can make you want to tear your arms off and slam your face on your keyboardLosing a great run can give you a heart attackUnsure post-EA future (Maybe)Flame TrapsRating: 9.5/10

												Update : Played 177 hours and finally I unlocked the B skin for my favorite character. Boy this game is hard.I played 43 hours of this, counting upwards day by day, and I am regretting every single second, I am playing this piece of garbage. But now to explain this, rather bad sounding beginning.This game, is great. Great at the gameplay, the roguelike, the weapons, not so much the enemies but still good enough. Another thing its good at is making me frustrated like hell. I have played so many times, so many hours AND I AM STILL NOT PAST THE SEVENTH GOD DAMN AREA! This game is good, its amazing! COULDNT LOVE OR HATE IT MORE!Seriously if you are a masochist, buy it. You are going to love it. You played Dark Souls and love it? Play this! You get about the same "GIT GUD" garbage.But now to the real thoughts:This game is good. It actually is amazing. I love it dearly and I couldnt hate it more either. It is like Binding of Isaac if you take all the fun parts out and replace it with a literal bullethell from Touhou. Remember the Mom fight or Hush? And how hard they were? Now think of that in every single level past the first 4. Actually even the first 3 level can contain that. And I am not talking about a tiny room with one boss doing this. No, the level is big and filled with enemies that shoot at you and attack you if you are too close to them as well. And if you manage not to get hit, you will be happy. This however will most likely not be the case with all types of enemies running around, hitting you as you touch them.All in all, I give this game a "good" on my scale. It only reaches good because its frustrating as hell. Even more than "Binding of Isaac". Like, I didnt think there would be a game out there like that...Now back into the hell of this game...Urgh...

number of helpful: 61 of 106 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												Ultimately it just wasn't for me and I think it's fair to say it may not be for others too.Nuclear Throne gets a lot right. A lot! Visuals are off the charts, sound is fun, and the gameplay is as smooth as silk and satisfying to wield (I went with keyboard and mouse, but controller didn't feel half bad for a few rounds either). Now I hate comparing apples and oranges but you immediately get this sense of it being some sort of glorious love child of two fan favorites; Binding of Isaac and Risk of Rain. I was downright giddy after my first few runs. Unfortunately it lacks something vitally important that make both of those mainstays; There's just no sense of progression here. I may be getting worse at gaming but I just didn't feel like I accomplished anything after my first run. A first run that throws all sorts of character unlocks in your face and gives you a false sense of how the game will progress. It just really doesn't after that. Well, not for a long time anyway. The only thing that kept me going besides self loathing was that I received an "achievement" for killing a boss that I had not. So I felt obligated to end him at least once. And this alone gave me the bulk of my 15hrs of playtime. Because well, the game is a punishing hectic mess and that's how long it took to off the dude! Which I will say is not a bad thing on it's own but as I said, there is just no rewards or progression for your truly futile efforts.You unlock a character now and then when you notice a funky secret, but they rarely bring anything to the table that gets you over the next hump or obstacle in your way. For me, they never did. Its just you versus the cruel world of the game. 15hrs of playing and I have the same equipment at my disposal as I started with. You just get better on your own. Or in my case, you don't. And the biggest problem is that the brunt of this equipment comes in the form of random number generation. Your level upgrades are a roll of the dice and chances are, much more often than not, you won't get a chance to pick the upgrades you'd prefer. This makes the bulk of your runs a large step in quality below the runs featuring a perfect dice roll. And you better believe you'll make a stupid mistake and ruin your good setup should you get it! Pure punishment. I dunno, I guess I'm a wimp, but I'm tapping out. There was just something lacking for me. Much like the developers other title LUFTRAUSERS it gives you instant satisfaction but if you're in it for the long haul you better have some serious dedication and be an absolute glutton for punishment. I love the idea of what Vlambeer can accomplish with a program like Game Maker: Studio and it should be taken as inspiration to those aspiring. It is well worth a purchase in that regard. But no matter how smooth and pretty they keep making these titles I'm left with feelings of unbalance and lacking of progression. I wish I could "git gud" at this and see some of the later level stuff, but there's just no motivation to do so. Every one of my steps forward has 150 steps backwards in between with no new lessons learned. Beyond being a bundle game I can't recommend it. The fun just ends after 30mins and the punishment and praying to the "RNG Gods" begins. Proceed with caution.

content:

								Have you ever wanted to play as the illuminaughty dorito spamming airhorns while shooting through hordes of bandits, a-hole scorpions, rats, sniper robots, crows with smgs, a giant robotic cerberus, cyborg wolves, necromancers, beings made of pure solidified radiation,  interdimensional police, the teenage mutant ninja turtles, then overthrow a giant throne that kills all your friends before attaning it's final form, proceed to loop and do everything for an eternal cycle until you get shot too much and decide to warp back to your space mansion? then you'll love this game, even in it's unfinished form. tough but exciting, this game is truly a bullet hell masterpiece.boring version of what I said:Basically you play as an outlaw in a post-apocolyptic world looking for the Nuclear Throne, an almighty source of radioactive power. the journey is not safe however, and is frought with much danger, which is why you collect "rads" to level up and gain amazing mutations to make the quest an accomplishable task. The game plays as a top-down rogue-like action game, and is basically what happens when you mix binding of isaac and borderlands together, slap on some retro-ish graphics, then cover it in bullet hell smegma. I thoroughly enjoy this game and hope you do too. ( hopefully featuring Dante from Devil May Cry & Knuckles).

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												One of the best top-down shooters ever created, Nuclear Throne is a challenging, fast-paced ♥♥♥♥-'em-up that makes every run intense. With procedural generation and a wide variety of characters and weapons, and the goal of always getting further even once you've beaten the throne, it never gets boring. The post-apocalyptic style is awesome and everything is designed really well from both gameplay and design standpoints.My only gripe is that lategame (loop 2+) could have been balanced better, it usually becomes a massive bullet spam that forces you to either always have a melee weapon to clear projectiles or hug corners and slowly get rid of enemies, which kinda whithers down the shoot em up aspect for me. Regardless it's still incredibly fun at this point and pushes you to keep trying to get further (which is still very hard).I highly recommend trying this game at some point, it's definitely worth it's full price.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												Nuclear Throne is a procedurally generated twin stick shooter, set in a zany post-apocalyptic world, Unlike most games of its kind, the right stick is used for aiming but you have to press your controller's trigger to actually shoot bullets/shells/grenades...The game does many things very well. The shooting feels as good as it gets short of holding an actual weapon in your hand (at least I think so, I never held one). Enemy AI is well balanced for this kind of arcade game. They hide around corners but not so well as to make the game tedious.Nuclear Throne scatches an itch similar to that of the Binding of Isaac, but with shorter sessions. Both games are arcade shooters, procedurally generated, and unbalanced by design (Nuclear Throne is much harder though). I still prefer Isaac, because it has much more content and variety. After nearly 20 hours, I begin to grow tired of Nuclear Throne already, but those 20 hours have been very fun.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												In short, Nuclear Throne is a roguelite 2D top-down bullet hell dungeon crawler shooter.It takes many elements from the great pioneers of all of these (sub)genres, violently mashes them together and adds some more difficulty to the surprisingly well-smelling mess.You start off in the wasteland with... well, nothing but a bad gun with a bit of ammo really.As you kill all enemies to progress to the next randomly generated stage, you'll try to loot dead enemies and chests for better guns (that all play differently and are all better in certain situations), more ammo for those guns and rads (which give you the ability to mutate between stages) in a desperate attempt to not die horribly. (which WILL happen eventually)As you git gud, you will also unlock: new characters which encourage different playstyles, a  variety of improved golden weapons to start with in future runs to make delving down to the throne less hard, skins that don't do sh♥t, and challenging crowns to add even more spice to the pili-pili.Once you reach and kill the throne, the game will 'loop', throwing you back in the first stage with a lot more and harder enemies to kill (you). This process will repeat itself. UNTIL YOU DIEI have not played a whole lot of this game, but i'll be adding more to this review as i play and discover more.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												Another Vlambeer work of art. Fast-paced top-down roguelike mouse+keyboard (highly recommended) or dual stick shooter. I've happily poured hours into this game and will continue to do so without regret. Several characters to choose from, each with unique abilites and tradeoffs that are well designed to offer a challenging experience. Enemies are numerous and if you're like me, will kill you dead again and again, making it that much more gratifying to knock their block off with a shotgun blast. Or stick 'em between the eyes with a crossbow bolt. Or blow them to kingdom come with a cluster grenade. Or laser their face with lasery lasers. Etc., etc., etc.Music and sound design are on point, to be expected from this developer but worth a mention just the same.Very few gripes, none worth listing here. Beauty of a game.Everything hurtsPew pew pew pew

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								A crazy, hectic, and fun-as-hell top-down shooter! This game doesn't mess around. It throws you right into the action, and you must learn and adapt if you wish to survive.Despite this game's difficulty level, it is not unfair. With practice, you can learn how to efficiently deal with specific enemies and scenarios that you once thought you would never overcome. Dodging, positioning, and timing are all important skills to develop.The upgrades system is very simple, but helpful enough to keep things interesting. You can mix and match upgrades to find builds that suit your playstyle. Not to mention all of the unique weapons you can find hidden in the wastelands.I can be a hothead when it comes to games, but this game does not particularly upset me when I lose. I just try again, and I don't mind trying again because of how enjoyable the game is to play! If the genre interests you, it is definitely worth a try. Especially if you manage to get a 33% off coupon for it!

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne is a phenomenal game that doesnt cease to please. No matter your skill level, the game constantly brings new things into the mix to help you or to harm you ( every single week). Also regardless of skill, this game bring endless hours of fun. Unlike other Rouge-Lite games, as of now, this game provdies 12 unique characters all with their own play-styles. Want to be a tank, Crystal is for you. Enjoy high-risk playing, Melting will suit you nicely. Nuclear Throne does an excellent job of incorporating a character to suit practically anyone. Nuclear Throne also adds a feature that is different than most other games of it's type; ammo management.  Just when you think you are about to beat Lil' Hunter and make it to the throne room, you can run out of ammo and it can mean almost certain death. This can influence your gun choices drastically, is it really worth taking the triple machine gun? Or the Hyper Rifle? As opposed to a Heavy Crossbow? On the subject of guns, every gun feels relatively different, not like the developers were lazy and reskinned a gun and called it new. Overall, Nuclear Throne does a great job of challenging anyone while still making sure that it is beatable. I would personally reccommend it to anyone i know, as Nuclear Throne provides something for all types of Gamers.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												I mean this out of the bottom of my heart when I say this game is amazing. It is a phenominally good game to play with HOURS of play value! To simply put it, the game is like if Binding of Isaac and Fallout had a baby. The game has ton of unlockables and achievements that really test how good you are at the game and it can be a real challenge to get some of them. If I had to say so, this game is definetly not for a casual gamer looking for a laid-back play-style, if you play this prepare for intense shaking, heavy breathing, and sweaty hands. Also alot of depression and potential crying from dying from rediculos ways (DEM CAR EXPLOSIONS). Anyway, if I had to rate this game on a scale from 1 to 10, I am going for a 9.5 out of 10. .5 being excluded because there are some bugs that can ruin an entire run. Examples include: 1: Sometimes entering an area called the Crown Vault after doing something specific will cause a rare bug in which tiles and enemies that don't appear in the area spawn. 2: Sometimes the game crashes randomly at the start of some boss fights. For me this is COMPLETELY random. And finally 3: Sometimes when walls are exploded the top of the wall still coveres the floor so you can't see ANYTHING! This has ended so many runs for me because of enemies running after me under the wall so I didn't have time to aim or run. Anyway these bugs are rare so I still say this game is a definet must-get if your a thrill-seeker who loves to have adrenline rushes when you play games. :3
