content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
Early Access Review
Nuclear Throne is a very well made roguelite twin-stick shooter that incredibly fun and satisfying to play that I would highly recommend to anyone who enjoys roguelikes. There are six different categories of guns; Bullet, Shell, Arrow, Laser, Explosive and Melee. Each one of them feels different and unique so there will be a preferred weapon type for everyone. The gunplay in the game is very well done, all the weapons feel like they have a weight to them and it is fun to mix different weapons to find the perfect combination. The randomized nature of the game means that players will get to experiment and experience all the weapons. Furthermore, it’s very satisfying to learn the how the weapons work and master the controls of the variety weapons.There are a variety of character which have unique abilities such as rolling and shields and player also levels up their character through the run which will unlock new attributes, leading to some unique builds that will adjust how the player will play the game, meaning every run is unique. There is also daily challenges which will spawn a new run every day and you can replay the same map for a day and try to place on the leaderboard, rather than a randomized level each time, creating a variety of game modes.Every stage in the game feels unique with new enemies introduced that you learn the patterns. The game has elements of Shmup games with a large amount of bullets flying towards you and can get overwhelming but it’s very satisfying find a path through the enemies and beat the level.Even though the game can be very challenging, the difficulty curve is not too steep so that it doesn't become too hard for players too quickly, the player is always in a space where it is possible to fight out of any challenge.The sound design and graphics both build a very unique atmosphere, the music often matches the settings perfectly and is very invigorating when fighting the enemies. The pixel graphics are very detailed and unique that gives the game great charm and character that is wonderful to look at, all the enemies are instantly recognizable and interesting to fight.This is also a paragon of early access games. The devs have made over 90 weekly updates to the game that add new features such as weapons, characters, as well as adjust and rebalance gameplay. They listen to the community; they deserve some respect for their commitment to the game in a landscape of exploitive developers who want to release buggy, broken games to get a quick buck, such as DayZ and countless other scams. Nuclear Throne started out a great game and has only gotten better over time as more things get added to the game, as it soon approaches its full release, it sets a standard for early access games on Steam and it is a shame that this level of dedication to a game isn’t seen very often. Overall, definitely worth picking up to support good developers and a great game, looking forward to the final release coming up soon!

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												I have this game on my PS4, so don't let my playtime fool you.Where do I begin? This is why we love indie devs! For every Jumpix Jump, there are absulote gems of games like this. I bought it on my PS4 as an impulse buy because I liked the pixel characters. I had no idea what I was in for. I bought it again through Humble Bundle just because I loved it so much. (I know Sony doesn't give indie devs that much revenue.)  I never done that before. I could have given that money to charity. What am I doing with my life? (I don't regret it. I support indie devs!)This game is the hardest game I have ever played. It's harder then Shovel Knight, Dark Souls and Bloodborne. However, it's not cheap or unplayable like a lot of old NES games. Every mistake is your own fault. Only a few bad spawns made the game feel unfair. Otherwise, this game is based purely on your skill as a player and willingness to learn it's rules. This is great game for speedrunners and competetive players. It takes skill to play this game good. And once you finally master it, it throws a new trick at you.I am what you would call a casual gamer. I'm not a big fan of difficult games, let alone bullet heaven type games. However, I was immediatly pulled in by this game. I'm addicted. You die and die again, and yet I can't stop hitting the retry button. That is amazing that a game this hardcore could pull in a casual player like me.I grew up on the NES and the SNES. (I'm young, btw. Second hand gaming rules.) Those are my two favorite systems, and this game feels like it would belong among the most legendary and classic games on those systems. I love the graphics. The pixel art is beautiful. Every character, enemy and stage has their own personality. Obviously a lot of love went into this game. This just goes to show what can be done with Gamemaker studio. I actually really love Gamermaker games when they're done well. I think there's a charm to them.When it comes to the gameplay, there a million ways to play. Every character has their strengths and weaknesses, and along with various randomized mutations and a HUGE arsnel of weapons - there is a lot you can do! Which really adds to replayability. You can easily get 500+ hours from this little game. It's full to the brim with secrets, character and charm that will keep you coming back for more. As a NES/SNES fanboy, I think this game just trumped a lot my classic favorites. This is my favorite game by far and goes to show why we need indie games. I have plenty of mainstream AAA games with top notch graphics, but I come back to little games like these more often than not.I can not praise this game enough. It's a little masterpiece of an indie game. What are you waiting for? Get it. Through Humble Bundle if you can, if you want to support this dev more. (Go to the game's website. The link is there.)I have a few tips for you:- You will die. A lot. You will get frustrated and grit your teeth and curse this game. Take a break. Play another easier game (preferably Stardew Valley) or put the controller down, and then come back. You'll realize that when you're calm, you're doing better then when you were stressed.- There is no pointless character. Even if a character seems useless to you, every one is cleverly planned out to have strengths. It's up to you to figure out what those are. (Or you could just look it up, like a cheater.)- Crystal is BY FAR the easiest character to play as, but I would only play as him if you're just starting and getting used to the game's difficulty. Because of his special ability, learning how to play the game with this character can be counter-productive. You need to learn how to dodge.- There are plenty of secrets, but most are obvious once you realize how to find them. Keep your eyes open.EDIT: - Also, there's one more thing I'd like to mention. The screen shakes a bit in partcularly chaotic fights. If this bothers you, there is a setting in the options to turn screen shaking off. I did this and prefer the game with it off.I bought this game for co-op. It's awesome. In an age when were seeing less and less couch co-op games, this is really appreciated. Thank you devs for giving me such an amazing experince.NOTE: (13/03/2016) As of the time of writing this, the PS4 version of this game, however, is unfortunetly broken. Once you get past the beginning stages, it could crash at any time for no reason. It doesn't happen often, but it's annoying as heck. I have yet to hear any word on this being fixed. Darn it. Also, the game seems like it doesn't fit on the screen. I tested the PC version and it doesn't have this problem. It's especially noticeable on the tutorial level. The text is almost totally blocked because it goes off the screen. No word on this being fixed. I would recommend the PC version. I love this game to death, BUT it's unbelievable that ANYONE could release a game on the Playstation store in this state! This problem probably hurt the game more than we know.I would still prefer playing on my PS4 though, as the crashes aren't often enough to render the game unplayable.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								After hitting 40 hours of playtime in a week during the holidays, I can say only one thing.Wow.This game is truly amazing. Not only does its playstyle allow newer players to learn the game, but it also lets advanced or more experienced players still have fun. The game is fun, and since you restart from the beginning at every death, makes you cautious around certain enemies and allows you to learn from your previous mistakes. Additionally, I love the mutations, and like how you can choose certain mutations to fit your own playstyle and make the game more fun. Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone, and promise that it will provide hours of enjoyable play-time.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												Its out. Its finally out. Finally out in a good way, not in the "Ugh, this is taking so long...". To be honest, I had no idea what I was doing when I first played this game, and I wasn't really that interested in it. I watched Northernlion play his daily runs and whatnot, and with every episode I watched I wanted to play the game more. So I finally actually gave the game a proper go. It was fun but I still didn't know what was going on. I continued to play Nuclear Throne more and more and with every playthrough I was learning and I was getting better. [I've only looped once]. This game is now AMAZING. Vlambeer could've released it a long time ago but they decided to keep it in Early Access. With every update I wanted to play more! Vlambeer have done MASSIVE updates for this game week after week and its made the game so GOOD. It feels so satifying to see a game grow into something this... this phenomenal! It was a bumpy ride at the begginning, but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ was it worth it for me to stick around with this game. When it was in Early Access it was awesome, and now its even more awesome now that its released. And even better, Vlambeer are going to continue to update Nuclear Throne, and expanding its story and the game. This game is amazing. I love, and I'm glad I gave it another chance when I first bought it. Thank you Northernlion and thank you Vlambeer for making one of the best indie games on Steam. Its been a pleasure to see it grow and develop into something great.Thank you for taking the time to read my review. It was honestly a tribute to Vlambeer in all honesty. I love Nuclear Throne and I hope everyone else does too!

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Nuclear Throne is an amazing arcade-style top-down shooter with startling amounts of replayability. It's fast-paced and not once have I been bored in all of my playtime.The characters are the most colorful and creative I have ever witnessed, which is extremely surprising, considering most of them are simple one-word concepts drawn up as people. Or gods. Or even fish. I don't know how it works, but it does.The gameplay is perfectly designed; the mutations are really satisfying to pick, and get even more satisying as you get better at the game and actually know which mutations do what.For those that are iffy on the difficulty of the game, I can say the difficulty is definitely high, but I consider it a large feature of the game. The goal is to reach the Nuclear Throne, and it's not expected of you to do it on your first try, but when you do, (took me 50-60 hours) you will feel so accomplished. Everything in your entire life will light up in stunning clarity, and just as you commence the final fight, ready to take your Nuclear Throne...you die because you didn't know there was a sudden-death beam at the beginning. you're welcomeBut it was worth it, because then you knew it was possible, and you could do it again with an entirely different character, different levels, different guns, and all the same glorious feeling of killing everything in your sight.It's fun. I promise.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm only about 2 hours in at the time of this review, and this is probably the hardest I've ever raged at a video game.Nuclear Throne is incredibly fast-paced and frantic. It takes time getting used to the sheer amount of chaos happening at once. The game throws you right into the action with no tutorial or simplistic stages. When it comes to figuring out the game, you are pretty much left to your own devices.This game is also INCREDIBLY HARD. Some enemies shoot out a ruthless spray of bullets, and it only takes a couple of them to kill you. With no recovery time, your character can die within seconds. Fortunately, each stage has a plethora of different weapons lying around, and each one of them has various pros and cons. Each character has a special move specific to them, from deflecting bullets, to slow motion, to summoning allies for help and so on. This makes each character play very differently, adding to the replayability. Your character also levels up, and can pick from random mutations in order to receive various perks.With randomly generated levels and level up bonuses the game is endlessly replayable. Which is a good thing, because you will die A LOT. And every death sends you back to the start of the game. And there's no bonuses to make the game any easier when you restart. Nuclear Throne expects you to beat the game all at once, by only using your skills. The game is still a little rough around the edges, but it has a lot more polish than most other early access games. And it looks like Vlambeer is doing a great job at constantly working on the game. If you have the money, get this game. It's one of the best (if not the best) twin-stick shooters that I've ever played, even at this stage. Just keep in mind that getting to the Nuclear Throne is far from easy.

number of helpful: 31 of 55 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
Product received for free
												Nuclear Throne is a top-down roguelike shooter, and a relatively good one at that; you can drag the window size to fit any resolution you so desire. In terms of gameplay, you select a character, run around, shoot enemies, dodge bullets, pick up better guns, repeat. A tried and true formula that works very well with games of its genre.I'm on the fence about this game, and if I could give it a "neutral" review, I would; since Steam only has "Recommended" vs "Not Recommended", I decided to lean towards the latter (therefore allowing all the rabid fanboys to downvote this without a second thought to help combat their own insecurities). Whatever helps you sleep at night, it doesn't change my review and what I have to say about the game.The gameplay is all fine and good, but this game honestly feels more luck-based than skill-based. That's not to say this game is not skill-based; utilizing cover to avoid bullets, then shooting them at opportune moments is a key element of this game. I say the game is luck based because of primarily two things; the levelling system, and the procedural generation of each stage.The levelling system is very straightforward; kill enemies, collect their exp drops, level up, select one of four randomly provided power ups at the end of the stage, continue. This is all fine and good, except for how (obviously) some power-ups are much better than others. Several times have I been starved for an ability that would prove most useful because the RNG failed to provide. As for the procedural generated levels, several times have I had a somewhat decent run instantly taken away from me by spawning in the next level surrounded by enemies with absolutely no cover, obliterating me within seconds. Regardless of who you are and how long you've played these kinds of games, no amount of 'skill' can allow someone to pop into a brand new level and instantly avoid a slew of bullets coming from literally every direction while effectively fighting back. Sometimes the level spawns many enemies into a tight room with a 1-block entryway, making it almost impossible to clear it out without taking some form of damage. To add insult to injury in such scenarios, many enemies move very quickly and do collision damage. My use of the term 'procedural generation' is stretching it for this game; the only thing inherently procedural about it is the fact that there's never a part of the map that's inaccessible in some form.Comparing other 'difficult' games (such as Spelunky, Hotline Miami, and Super Meat Boy), you die a lot, but each death in those games feels like it was your fault that you died, and you learn something from it that can be used to improve your next attempt. Nuclear Throne does not provide that. Each death feels cheap and the only thing you can really tell yourself in terms of improvement if you decide to try again is "get better". Have you ever asked a teacher for help, and they simply told you to "do better"? I have. He was subsequently fired. I've seen and played games that are hard for the right reasons; Nuclear Throne is hard for the wrong reasons.Of course, all of what I said can be "expected of roguelikes", and "if you don't like that kind of game, don't play it". Roguelike fans call it art, I call it poor game design.In conclusion, Nuclear Throne isn't a bad game by any means; it just has some glaring flaws that really take away from its long-term enjoyability. After all, only a masochist would enjoy repeatedly attempting something, only to result in failure with little to no sense of progress.

content:
Posted: March 11
												Oh boy, where do I start with this one;Nuclear Throne is a top-down roguelike shooter which features twelve unlockable characters (currently) and a wide array of weapons and enemies.The game also features many unlockables, such as golden weapons, different crowns and even different skins for characters.Onto the actual review; this game is a great one, a game in which you will love whole-heartedly but also have a deep hatred for simultaneously. Sometimes games can't land this right in the middle; leading to a rage-inducing game which isn't fun to play; but Nuclear Throne does it well. The somewhat difficult levels and multiple areas keep you coming back to complete more and more runs, not to mention the achievements too..Most of the characters have different abilites, such as Fish's rolling ability or Crystal's shielding; all character abilities are, by default, activated with the RMB. These become crucial in a run, some character's have pros and cons, some substitute ammo/HP for other buffs used during the game.The upgrades during this game impact the style, success and the difficulty of your run, with the upgrades coming everytime you "level up" in-game. This is achieved by finding and consuming "rads", obtained by killing enemies and/or finding rad capsules (little green bottles) throughout the level.The Daily and Weekly runs are also good for players who have completed the game fully (although this is very hard and is only achieved by a small percentage of players). The Daily is just a normal run, but you only get a single try, compete against others to get as many kills as possible (keep this is mind, the leaderboard is organised in kills, NOT distance of run). However the Weekly run is more specific, you get unlimited lives with the same leaderboard system (and a week to complete it, obviously) but only one character is playable and you sometimes even have weapon restrictions.Saying anymore would ruin the random surprises this game has to offer, so I'll leave it up to you, the reader, to discover these for yourself.Overall this game is very well made, a nice balance of rage-inducing gameplay and satisfaction all put into one. I would easily recommend this game to anyone who is interested.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												Original review posted on October 26, 2015:This game is amazing. It is fun and simple, but it is ungodly difficult at the same time. The premise behind the game is simple. You start the game with two characters, these being Crystal and Fish. All characters have two uniquie things. Their passive and their active. Their passive is just that; an ability that will run in the background, influencing your attack patterns and the drops for players. Their active is also known as their right-click ability. Left-click is the basic attack and the default movement is WASD. Just using the two starting characters as an example, I will show how different playstyles can be from character to character.Crystal-Passive: More base health than any other character.-Active: A temporary shield that will reflect multiple bullets and protect you from others.Fish-Passive: Extra ammo recieved-Active: A dodge rollNew review after multiple updates and a very particular mod release:Ah, it's nice to be back to playing this game regularly, but now, there is an extremely different experience of which I must say I enjoy partaking in.Now, if you have looked at the tags, it likely mentioned "Local Multiplayer" or "Local Co-Op," but that no longer matters(provided your computer isn't a toaster and your internet isn't an Explorer). There is now a mod(which has been mentioned in the latest news by Vlambeer, so you know it's good) called Nuclear Throne Together, and it does exactly what you think it does; it allows you to play online co-op(or even Vs. with some creative/idiotic friends), albeit at a few costs to the core game.If there was one thing I absolutely loved, it was unlocking all of the characters(and what few B-skins I unlocked before save-editing them in, but that's a different story). The journey felt important, but sadly NTT takes that away by automatically unlocking all characters and B-skins(I know that it does as my idiotic friend hadn't even unlocked Steroids and yet, he was able to play Rouge with her B-skin using the mod).While this certainly does detract from the appeal of the journey, the game is still far from kind and is honestly just downright vicious.Now, since I have basically informed you to get NTT as soon as you start playing the game, I should probably give you some information regarding the rest of the other characters.The first two characters unlocked, Fish and Crystal, I explained in the previous version of this review.The next character, Melting, is unlocked by dying for the first time. He literally looks like a skeleton with melting flesh.Passive-2 health, but recieves an extra Rad(NT's version of Experience) from every enemy(including enemies that don't drop Rads)Active-Explodes all corpses on screen.Next is Eyes, and he's a bit of an interesting character. Firstly, his passive only works on three levels(four, including 4-?), these three(four) being known as the Transition Levels. He's unlocked by reaching the first Transition Level, the Sewers(2-1).Passive-See in the dark(allows him to see the outside boundaries of your FoV in the transition levels)Active-Telekinesis(push bullets away, but pulls enemies and items towards you)Next up is Plant, and boy-oh-boy, do I hate Plant. Plant is unlocked by reaching 3-1(I think), and I only ever unlocked him out of neccessity.Passive-More speed(GOTTSA GO FEST!)Active-Shoot a snare(traps enemies inside of it and acts as a source of light on the Transition Levels).Ah, back to the characters I like, and next up is Yung Venuz(more commonly referred to in game as Y.V.). To unlock Y.V., try to pick up a screwdriver in the desert(1-1 to 1-3) and take it to 3-1(screwdrivers can be found almost anywhere, but it's easiest for them to drop in chests at the very beginning). At 3-1, there will be cars that will explode from too much damage, but there is one car in particular that stands out. Attack that car once with the screwdriver and press your activate button(for me, a mere keyboard user, it is E). You can thank me later.Passive-Higher fire rateActive-Pop Pop(shoot two rounds of ammo for the currently equipped weapon at the cost of a slightly delayed rate of fire)Now, reaching 5-1, we unlock Robot, an interesting(but in my opinion, kind of boring) character to play.Passive-Finds better tech(finds weapons of higher levels than what would drop on any other character)Active-Eat your weapon(consumes the weapon currently equipped as the primary to give ammo for the other weapon).Now, we arrive at 6-1, and here's where things get interesting. Steroids is up next, and he brings a whole slew of power to your arsenal.Passive-Inaccurate(this is okay) and fully automatic fire(no matter what the weapon is)Active-Attacks with the weapon equipped in the off-handYes, that's right. As the load screen will tell you time-and-time again, "Steroids can duel-weild."Okay, now we're getting into the spoiler zone, so read at your own risk.Next up is Rebel, a character that can only be unlocked by defeating the Nuclear Throne and ending your run by sitting on it.Passive-Restores half of damage taken when completing level(If she has 2/12(let's say remaining health is X and max health is Y) remaining health when you complete the level, you'll enter the next level with 7, as (Y-X)/2 rounded down in this case would be 5, so (Y-X)/2+X would be the overall equation for her passive.Active-Okay, this one's a bit complex, so bear with me. On her first right click when entering a level, she will lose one HP and a minion will spawn. The minion will last 20 seconds before exploding, but there is a way to extend its lifespan. By right-clicking again, another minion will spawn, and this resets the timer for the first ones life(presumably, it heals them). However, every minion spawned after the first on a single level takes up two HP rather than one(you cannot kill yourself with this ability).Okay, this next character is kind of strange. Horror is unlocked by defeating Horror, who will only spawn when you skip the Rad Canisters on two levels in a row(as such, it is easiest to unlock him on 1-3, but I have accidentally had him spawn in on 4-1 and proceed to end my run).Passive-When choosing a mutation by leveling up, he will have 5 choices(as compared to the usual 4)Active-Ability to shoot accumulated Rads in a concentrated beam as a tertiary weapon(all Rads used in this way will only be regained if they actually hit their target). Also, Rad absorption will be paused when this ability is being used, so keep that in mind).Next is Rogue, and she is definitely the hardest to unlock. First off, when fighting the Nuclear Throne, destroy all of the generators(activated with the Throne's giant laser beam) and then kill the Throne. A portal will open up which leads to the Throne II fight. Beating the Throne II will let you loop, and that's how you unlock Rogue.Passive-All Rad Canisters become ammunition for her Portal Strike, and she's chased by the IDPDActive-Portal StrikeThe last two characters in the mod, Skeleton and Frog, though playable in the original game, they are hidden. Skeleton is only playable by being killed in a Necromancer's circle, and Frog is only playable by saving the Golden Frog Pistol to a character(which is no simple task).SkeletonPassive-4 HP, slowActive-Shoot for no armor at the potential loss of healthFrogPassive-Can't stop, won't stop tryna make the booty drop. Also, he can't be effected by toxic items.Active-Stops moving and begins charging a fart, which will poison anything that enters the toxic cloudSo, yeah, that's about it.I rate this game 9/11, too many cars exploding.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								The year is 21XX. The United States of America is a shadow of its former self, ravaged by nuclear war and Al Gore's climate change. Amongst the city ruins of Los Angeles, a group of mutants set out on an adventure to discover the fate of one of their friends who claimed to have discovered the location of the mythical 'Nuclear Throne'. Along the way, their friendship will be put to the test as they fight off tribes of hostile mutants and the I.D.P.D., human survivors of the first great patriotic Nuclear war who fled to underground bunkers and escaped the ravages of radiation.Featuring voice acting from an ensemble cast starring Corey Feldman, Karl Urban, John Cena, Keanu Reeves, Sharlto Copley, James Franco, Mila Kunis and Michael Pena as Fish.Vlambeer delivers a gripping tale of self-discovery, love, and acceptance of the other, all underpinned by a prophetic warning of the dangers of the nuclear, climate change, and unregulated fracking. A must play.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												One of the few early access game you can trust, and the only one i can trust.  The developers update the game almost weekly, they stream the development, and they are very responsible unlike many other early access developers, they deserve this money.  So now let's actually talk about the game, the game is a 2 dimentional twin shooter rogue like action game that includes some rng (random number generation, or randomness), it has a lot of variation, when it comes to weapons, characters, enemies, levels, mutations and so on...  This kind of game may attract Binding of Isaac fans, Risk of Rain fans and so on.  It can be hard to learn and get into the game, but once you do you won't go back, it's fun, intersting, has many features like daily runs, unlocks and so on, and upcoming features like co-op, new content and so on...  currently the game is not finished but definitely playable, you have a final boss, an ending, even a way to continue after you finished the game, leaderboards so you can race with your friends on the dailys, and remember - it has a lot of replayabillity, and no end - so even if you finish a run you can start another one and it will be different and exciting!  ratings:-- Gameplay: 8/10 Soundtrack: 7.5/10 Replayabillity: 9/10 Artstyle: 8.5/10 Mechanics: 10/10

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								WARNING!!!         IF YOU ARE ABOUT TO BUY THIS GAME READ CAREFULLY THIS REVIEW!!! Introduction This game is made to apeal to really small audience.Its very hard and it will probably destroy your sanity if you dont have experience with top-down shooters.(even if you played anyone of the hotline miami games,it will be very challenging).Even as an eperienced gamer in this type of games the SMALLEST MISTAKE can end a very powerful run.You can be at full HP but still die in seconds to explosions or by touching sth with a lot of contat dmg,This game also doesnt have invinsibility frames meaning that you can get hit by 10 proectiles in 0,01sec.You will probably die by every enemy 5 times until you learn their paterns.If you have weak psychology dont try this game!!!GameplayThe games is very fair when it comes to ammo and health drops.It may sometimes spawn you in a difficult position surounded by enemies but with enought practice you will be able to survive them even with the starting weapon and no Mutations.The main objective of the game is to beat th NUCLEAR THRONE and survive as long as you can after that.Its a bullethell game so remember that u need to be focused on shooting as much as on doging the projectiles,which is hard after all.After you beat the throne u will have to repeat the game from the start with MORE enemies and Secret Bosses for each area.After killing an enemy he will drop RADS with are used to level up.Leveling up lets you chose a Mutation which will help you in the game like more more HP morebigger ammo capasity etc.You can chose one of 4 randomly given to you mutations after finishing the aeria (if you leveled up)Pros and ConsPros-Great Retro graphics-Nice music and weapon sounds-Challenging and adictive (countless hours of playing)-Tons of Playable characters wth unique abilities and passives-Fair but difficult health system -Balanced weapons -A lot of improvements and updates-Requires a lot of skill (luck matters only in 5% of the games sytuation)-Lots of weapons (more than 100 for sure)-A good amount of mutations to pick from (about 20)Cons-Small audience-Still has bugs since its in eary accessOverall ReviewIts a 10/10 game for the small audience that it targets.You will not find it fun if you rage easilybecause the smallest mistake can end your run.I have 300hrs in this game in total on multiple acc andits my Favourite game.As to the ''would you reccomend it thing'' i have mixed feelings just because of the difficulity of the game,but if you really love challenging games then this one should apeal to you.Have fun!!!

Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne's entire premise is for you to choose a mutant and kill a chair.It's an incredibly enjoyable, arcade-like game developed by Vlambeer, who knows when and how to listen to the community and always delivers quality. While Early-Access games are normally untrustworthy, Nuclear Throne is an exception. With simplistic, but charming visuals and difficult gameplay, Nuclear Throne is a great game to play to kill time or keep you away from your friends and family for a while. Reccommended for any gamer who's prepared to die and willing to push to see that radioactive chair.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Really addictive, and rightfully so. This game throws you into action immediately and can just as fast throw you out of it. It's fast, it's unforgiving and it's brutally challenging. It is everything a roguelike game should be.With a devoted team of developers updates arrive weekly with new features, bugfixing and balancing. Vlambeer also hosts a weekly stream on twitch with development process as well as responding to comments and complains about the game to make sure the audience is pleased with this work in progress masterpiece.When i first purchased this game i didn't play anything else for a good week or two, not only because there is a lot of ways to play the game (characters, weapons, upgrades etc.) but also because i was driven to see just how far i could get. See when the last boss is defeated you replay the game with the same items and upgrades, only now it's balls to the wall hard. That's where the real difficulty begins.Being in early access means it just keeps getting better, so i suggest purchasing it now to witness the small changes that improve the game every week. You will hate this game, then you'll love it, then you'll die to that annoying♥♥♥♥♥enemy and you'll hate it again. But when you loop for the first time and get that sick run with thousands of kills, you'll love it forever.#VerifyVenuz

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Amazing.Nuclear Throne is a rogue-like top-down action type of game, which has the player charging through randomly generated levels and fighting of hordes of bandits and various other mutated monsters.As the name suggests, Nuclear Throne takes place in a mutated world. You, the player has a choice of 12 balanced characters to try and reach the Nuclear Throne, the final boss and name of the game. In terms of gameplay, this game takes the cake. In earlier levels, things will seem boring, with safe spawns and easy victories. But progress further and you will see that things change very quickly. Later places such as the Frozen City are jam-packed with enemies, and your only hope is to keep moving.The player is also on the hunt for radiation. If you manage to collect enough, you can mutate. Each mutation has its strengths and weaknesses, and work well in specific situations, and this is what, in my opinion, gives the game an extra kick. Picking random mutations can get you killed, so choose wisely.With the many weapon choices, bosses bound to keep you on your toes and mutations that can either save you or kill you, this game can get intense. I wouldn't recommend this to people who aren't trying to game on the edge, and would rather stick to calmer titles. But for the gamers on the edge who want a fast-paced thriller, this is a much recommended game for you.

												Fast, fun, beautifully designed, and brutally unforgiving. On the surface the premise is simple: shoot the things until game over. But dive a little deeper into this colorful world and the details begin to shine. The uniqueness of the characters, enemies, environments, and guns - oh the guns - everything from the satisfying splats of your wasted foes to the taunts of bosses who have crushed you for the 100th time will keep you locked in. You will die many, many deaths. You will always come back for more.YOU DID NOT REACH THE NUCLEAR THRONEYOU DID NOT REACH THE NUCLEAR THRONEYOU DID NOT REACH THE NUCLEAR THRONEYOU ALMOST REACHED THE NUCLEAR THRONE...

								Nuclear Throne is a neat, twin-stick-shooting rogue-like, it's super fast paced, challenging, and a ton of fun to play. I'd mostly relate the gameplay to that of a randomized Hotline Miami, but with a variety of characters and run-based upgrades. The art style is great and the sound/music design is even better.Vlambeer is a wonderful development company and seem to be handling Early Access incredibly well, they definitely deserve your time. Check out their other stuff too, specifically LUFTRAUSERS and Ridiculous Fishing, all of their games are filled with charm and relatively unique, enjoy.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												I first got this game back in February after seeing some streams on Twitch. Little did I know what I was getting in to. As soon as it was done downloading I launched the game and already there it had already beaten me. As my ears were bleeding from the startup screen's scream of the death of a million mutants of the wasteland. That first "FLÄÄSHYN!" as you launch up the game will forever haunt my dreams.After adjusting the settings accordingly I went and selected Fish in the character selection and off we were. Who would've thought maggots would become my most feared enemy in any video game. And I rolled, and I rolled, and I rolled... And yet the same sentence kept popping up in my head; "Fish can roll."As hours went by and I got better at the game. I discovered new and exciting enemies, weapons, bosses and of course everyone's beloved 'Vlambeer Certified SAFE SPAWN©™'. But never ones did my mind falter from my one true goal: to reach the Nuclear Throne.So many mutants have died, so many bullets have been fired and so many bizarre bugs have helped me throughout my journey. After many tries and defeats I had reached my goal. The Nuclear Throne.After a long a tedious battle I had accomplished my goal. I had reached the Nuclear Throne. I had defeated the Nuclear Throne. And as I sat my thronebutt upon that sweet radioactive chair, I knew I had conquered... The Game of Throws.e

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you have even a passing interest in top-down shooters or roguelites/roguelike-likes, play this game. Even if you don't, I would strongly urge you to consider it anyway. This is one of the most fantastically executed games I have played in my life. Yes, it is in early access, and I will possibly revise this review once the game is fully released (The game currently does not have all the planned content implemented, and there are some bugs and balance issues), but I seriously doubt that my opinion of it will change to anything other than even greater love.On paper, everything seems pretty swell. The soundtrack is great. The presentation is absolutely incredible. Even the game's setting is very original and oddly intriguing, with a more cartoon-like, but still fairly gritty approach to the post-apocalypse aesthetic, complete with such details as an (admittedly not yet fully fleshed out) original language and hints to some fairly complex plot elements.In practice though, the game is even better. So, so much better. Nuclear Throne was built from the ground up to be as responsive and as visceral as possible. This is done through many seemingly insignificant factors such as attack animations, sound effects, and screen shake (which can be turned down, but unless you suffer from serious motion sickness, you're doing yourself a disservice by doing so). Combined with the considerable variety of weapons and fairly expansive character roster (both of which are still being added to), this creates a gameplay experience that is absolutely greater than the sum of its parts. Playing Nuclear Throne is enjoyable in ways that descriptions and even gameplay videos can't fully portray, because everything about the game is created to be satisfying on a psychological level.Also worth noting, the devs everything a independent development can and should ever be. Being in early access, the game is updated around once a week, and the developers are always active on the message boards, receptive to suggestions, and perfectly transparent. Buy the game.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hey, I have an idea! Let's select our favorite adorably creepy radioactive misfit and take the fight to a meddlesome group of rogues and abominations, all the while loading up on weapons and mutating to adapt to a dystopian hellscape! Sound good? Hell yeah, it does! Oldschool graphics, a soundtrack that inspires the ol' desperado frame of mind, a great variety of characters, weapons and enemies and the ability to mutate with each new level are some of the many perks of fighting your way through a post-apocalyptic wasteland, trying to get yourself a little farther than you got last time! This is one of those rare games in which you die... A LOT... and yet, it never seems to get on your nerves when you do! It just makes you want to give it one more go! I can honestly say that I've been an exhausted wreck for work on more than one occasion due to wanting one more bid for the throne! ...Whether that's a positive criticism on the game or a negative one for my own sense of priority, I'll have to get back to you on. Point being, this game is highly addictive and an adrenaline rush! Whether you're looking to spend a day at it, or just kill a few minutes before having to be somewhere, it's an all-around winner! I'd recommend this game like I'd recommend eating food on a regular basis: it just makes sense to do so, and you're ony hurting yourself to contradict! 10/10!

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												This game is absolutely fantastic, gorgeous sprite art,  fun game play, high replay value, challenging, great sound track, and just all around a fantastic time for those who enjoy bullet hell style gameplay.  Sometimes the map generated or the area in which you spawn can be frustrating because a level might be incredibly difficult with a bad spawn (ie no cover surrounded by enemies) and easy with a good spawn (cover, space between you and enemies.)  However with randomly generated maps this is bound to be an issue and if you get a bad spawn and die you just start over as always.  With a game like this it takes a  lot of practice and patience, I wouldn't reccomend this game if you're not prepared to put in the time to build up your skills in order to advance.  However if you are willing to put in a lot of practice then I find it very rewarding with unlockable characters, items, skins, and secret areas as you progress towards the nuclear throne.  Overall I definitely think it's worth the money and then some.

Early Access Review
								(Just a note:This game is way more difficult than Binding of Issac). So this game is about 12 mutants fighting through 7 well designed levels to the Nuclear Throne. I have played this game for long enough to say that you have a 100% chance of death in this. Runs aren't meant to last forever, as entering a portal increases the difficulty by 1 every time. That makes more monsters spawn.  You can have over 40 weapons of melee, bullets, energy, bolts, shells and explosives. They each can be intresting to use. When you level up, you get to choose 4 mutations. They are randomly set. I have no complaints about this game, yet it might be difficult at first.

												First of all, this game is very hard. I don't reccomend pcking up the game unless you are an expert at bullet hells. Feel free to try it out even if you don't like shooters, because it is a lot of fun. This game has been in early access for a little over two years, and being almost finished, Nucleaar Throne is getting better and better. What this game has:~10 unlockable characters, each with unique gameplay and abilities~Daily runs to test yur skill against other players for leaderboard highscore~Over 110 weapons to use~Looping feature for infinite gameplay~Bosses, each with a different stragety of killing youand many more features!Overall Nuclear Throne is a great game that challenges players to reach the throne over and over again, while also getting better weapons, newer strageties, and dodging skills. I have been playing this game since a year after it came out in early access, and it has a special place in my heart. Anyway, good luck, and have fun!

Early Access Review
								Everything Vlambeer develops ends up turning into gold. This game, even being early access, is my favorite Vlambeer title to date.  Think Hotline Miami meets rogue-like mutant monster infested wastelands. Awesome weapons, mutant upgrade. Gameplay is tight. I love the way the game camera moves. If you don't hold up well with camera shake they give you the option to adjust it under settings. Should also mention the soundtrack is kickass and fits perfect with the game's universe.  Looking back at their history of releases this should be no suprise. Lots of replay value. Good luck surviving long enough to getting to the Nuclear Throne. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This is the shortened version of my original Slovak review, which can be found here:http://www.madhouse.sk/152/nuclear-throneIt's a pretty quick traslation, so I apologize if it's not perfect.Rather than explaining the basic mechanics, I'll only talk about what I personally think is good and bad with Nuclear Throne. Steam won't let me post the full review anyway. If this is still too long for you, skip to the conclusion at the end.____Nuclear Throne might seem like a shallow indie title at first...and you could not be more wrong for thinking that. There's a surprising amount of depth, which is the reason why it's still fun to play, after the amount of hours I've put into it.Even though it is one of those games that I really love, and I do recommend it, it needs to be said that THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. This game is hardcore. Many people claim that it's the most difficult and the most frustrating game they have ever played. SO..if you aren't into rogue-lite and bullet hell, you can stop reading right now. If proceduraly generated content is not your thing, or you are not particularly skilled FPS player (even thought that entire genre), it may be hard for you to really enjoy chaotic nature of Nuclear Throne. However…if things mentioned above check all your boxes, and you feel strong enough to overcome first several hours full of frustration, then feel free to continue reading.Organized chaos (the good)There are many thing that I like about Nuclear Throne. The thing that stands out the most to me is not the sheer amount of content and possibilities, but the way they've tied it all together. The game has many ways how to keep you moving and thinking, and punishes you for every misstep you make. This is the level of depth and that special "something", that will have you coming back over and over again.Despite the random nature of the game, I found Nuclear Throne to be more skill based, than, let's say BoI or Risk of Rain. Sure, those games are a lot of fun…when you get the right drops. At least, that's my take on it. Nuclear Throne takes part of that problem away. You won't ever be completely OP, because the game is so unfair, that mutations don't make all that much of a difference…and they certainly won't get you to the throne by themself. And if you're good enough, even with bad build, you can have a great run. You're getting better yourself, your skills get better. Doesn't matter if RNG has a bad day. Also, let's not forget to mention sound design, that is perfect. Everything, and I mean everything in this game, has it's own sound. Once you'll get into, it will help you a great deal to understand what the hell is going on on the screen. I can't stress enough how important this is in the game, where you can get killed by something you can't see at the moment. Also, soundtrack is ♥♥♥♥ing great, and I still listen to it from time to time even when not playing.The last big possitive, that is kind of hard to describe, is the overall gameplay and the feel of the game. That's something that Vlambeer excells at, and you will know what I mean if you've played Luftrausers or Super Crate Box. Controls are tight, everything feels right even though you are not sure why. There's something very visceral about the wa it plays. And the most important thing - the gameplay is fun, even though you are not very good at the game yet."It's not fair, it's not right." (the bad)It's little bit hard for me to talk about what's bad here, because I see the game differently after the time I've spend playing it. But I'll try my best.The biggest downside to this game may be the time you have to put in, to actually get skilled enough and be able to see more, than just first couple of levels. That's pretty funny, because this is actually game that you can play, when you have just a couple of minutes to kill. Playthoughs last 10-15 minutes, of course they can strech to hour or more, as you get better and better. To fully explain what I'm trying to say here - I've beaten throne for the first time after playing the game for 60 hours. SIXTY. That just may be too much for some. That said, I'm someone who can get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥very much, very quickly…so if it wasn't fun for me to try and beat the game, I would ditch it half a year ago. Also, the whole game is locked on 30 FPS, which may seem like a terrible idea for a game as frantic as this one. Not only that, but there are times, where the framerate dips even lower, because there's just too much stuff going on at the same time. Now, I know this may sound stupid to you, but I don't mind any of that. Freezeframes are an actual feature of the game (no, really). They are actually helpful, as they give you those fractions of the second to realize what's going on and act accordingly. BUT, I know some may have problems with that, so that's why I'm telling you about it. Also, I don't know what's up with that 4:3 format. At the time of writing this, we are at update 97. As of now, there are still some bugs; also daily/weekly modes are pretty much unplayable, since leaderboards don't work. That said, I believe that Vlambeer will fix this as soon as they can. Nuclear Throne is imo one of the best examples of Early Access done right…Last, but not least - the game is ridiculously unfair at times. You will encounter situations that seem absolutely hopeless, because they really are. And even though the game lets you try different play styles, some just won't work very well…and that's a bit frustrating, to say the least.ConclusionNuclear Throne is the best game in it's genre imho, and my personal GOTY. If you're looking for a hardcore shooter, that will provide you with endless hours of fun and tears, for the price, this is the best deal. Despite being procedurally generated, it doesn't feel completely random and your success actually depends on your skills, and not just RNG. However, it will take you a great amount of time to reach the throne, and that might just be too much to swallow for some.Nuclear Throne covers the surprising amount of depth behind it's cute, yet weird pixel-art aestetic. But once you get into it, every beaten boss will be one of the most rewarding videogame experiences. You'll try again and again…and with the amount of content and replayability, you definitely can! But as I've mentioned before, this game is not easy, and it sure as hell isn't fair. You have to be the special kind of masochist to truly understand the beauty of Nuclear Throne. Rating: 9/10+ amount of content and replayability+ fun, arcade-like gameplay+ guns and mutations+ sound design - daily/weekly not working (at the moment)- occasional bugs- sometimes ridiculously unfair

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne is a top down rogue-like shooter set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland featuring animal mutants as the stars of the show. There is some backstory to be had there, but it's out of the way once the game starts up. And boy, is there a game to be had.Staple to Vlambeer's output, the game features hugely satisfying combat - with shots giving out appropriate amounts of screen shake, freeze frames and audio feedback upon pulling the trigger. You'll learn to love the impact of the shotguns and the sniper like efficiency of the crossbow. The weapons have been given loving amounts of attention, between tweaking, balancing and playtesting there is bound to be something for everyone.  The levels themselves are randomly generated, akin to the way Spelunky or other games of that ilk work. You'll have to navigate through several themed worlds, amassing rads (experience) and weapons along the way. The experience unlocks perks - gameplay perks you'll have to decide upon, the majority of which can greatly shape your playstyle and tactics. Defensive and offensive options abound for the players who like to play safe or for those who need more risk and reward. You'll find yourself on one hand (or two if you're playing Steroids) wielding increasingly massive amounts of firepower, while coping with the snowballing odds. Bands of enemies become hordes, and you'll find yourself in pure glee as you lay waste to everything before your eyes. Nothing can stand between you and victory, noth...oh wait. Death again. The game is hard, and you'll initially find yourself inching to survive. You'll have to observe individual enemy behaviors, learn to understand the baiting nature of the game, and capitalize on every bit of terrain on the battlefield. With enough time you'll find yourself at the Nuclear Throne...only to loop the game and turn up the difficulty to 11. The game features, single and local co-op action (still WIP), with dailies to add something to come back to everyday. I await the final release with (fish) baited breath.

content:
Posted: March 30
This review is created for  My Curation Page.  Skip to the bottom for my Final ThoughtsI purchased this game as a part of the Humble Freedom BundleNuclear Throne is a frantic post-apocalyptic rogue-like shooter bullet hell set in a universe inhabited by mutants and monsters. Made by the same developers who made games such as Super Crate Box and Luftrausers, Nuclear Throne is yet another notch on the belt of great games by Vlambeer.GraphicsNuclear Throne sports pixel art 2D graphics, with each world being unique and completely different. The setting of the game differs between contrasting enviornments such as a desert wasteland and a frozen city. There are many different types of enemies which all look unique as well as menacing, as well as bosses in certain areas in each playthrough, each with completely differing looks related to their enviornment (my favorite is Big Dog). From bugs to robots, from rats to crystals, Nuclear Throne has a wide variety of odds and ends from all corners of fiction. Audio & SoundtrackNuclear Throne has very nice adventurous music that really helps set the tone of the game. You don't want to listen to boring orchestral music as you fight your way through nuclear wastelands since the rhythm and speed of the music doesn't match the frantic bullet hell style of Nuclear Throne. For the first couple playthroughs of Nuclear Throne, you'll be hearing a lot of the same music because every Area uses one or two different tracks. If you spend a lot of time in say, the first Area, you'll be hearing a lot of the same music, but as you progress deeper and deeper towards the end, you'll hear all sorts of music made by the wonderful composer "Jukio Kuabee Kalio".GameplayNuclear Throne is a frantic roguelike bullet-hell game that keeps you on your toes and the edge of your seat. One mistake can very well be your last mistake in a playthrough. If you get yourself into a sticky situation, surrounded by enemies, it may very well be your chance to say goodbye to that playthrough. There are many different types of playable characters, with my favourite being "Crystal". Every character has different abilities that you can use with your right mouse button. For example, Crystal can shield himself for a short period, deflecting some shots back at the shooter. As I mentioned before, some areas have their own boss. For example the first Area, the desert, has Big Bandit, who shoots a machine gun and dashes through walls. The further you get into the game, you unlock chances to unlock a Crown, an item that alters the flow of the game that also bears consequences.StorylineThe storyline of the game is mainly told to you through small snippets of exposition in the load screens. If you are looking for a deeper take of the Nuclear Throne storyline, you'll have to go to the Nuclear Throne wikia and look at the trivia for characters or bosses. I would like the story aspect of Nuclear Throne so much more if there was little bits of exposition, say, after you defeat a boss. I would really love to know the backstory for Big Dog, my favorite boss in Nuclear Throne. Final ThoughtsOverall, I really enjoy playing Nuclear Throne. You can easily pick up a game and play for a few minutes, but you could also easily find yourself into a 30 minute or longer playthrough. If you are a fan of bullet hell or roguelike games, then I think you'd enjoy playing Nuclear Throne, however, if you are looking for a game with a deep story, then Nuclear Throne most likely isn't for you (unless you can swallow the storyline aspect and just enjoy the explosions and bullets). I can definitely see myself playing Nuclear Throne to completion more and more in the near future.Rating:Graphics: 8.1/10Audio: 7.6/10Gameplay: 8.4/10Overall: 8.0/10Enjoy the review? Please check out  My Curator Page  as well as my  YouTube Channel .

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												This game is a top down twin stick shooter with rouge-like elements. Each and every play through is never the same. This game is ♥♥♥♥ing hard. I mean really hard. This is the Dark Souls of twin stick shooters. Each map randomly generates the field and weapons are also generate randomly depending how far you gotten. Example, in the beginning you get random low tier weapons from chests as in higher levels you get higher tier weapons. The enemies get stronger the further you go and you have to play it smart by finding cover. This game requires some skill and a lot of luck. More than half the time I either die from being spawned in the worst spot on the field or accidentally kill myself with a grenade launcher or some explosive weapon. Either because I was being dumb or the enemy was too close by running towards you. This game may be hard but it's a lot of fun. Great soundtrack, very responsive controls, my only complaint is that there is no online co-op mode. There is local co-op but no online. Still it's a great game and addicting. It's a 8.5/10 for me.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Brutal, unforgiving, HARD AS HELL. This game hits all the right switches for a fantastic roguelike shooter. Probably one of my favorite games of all time. This game has a steep learning curve, endless replay value (in my opinon), a boatload of content, especially in the "post game" parts. While "post game" really is just the start to the game. Excellent gunplay, weapons feel unique, satisfying and most of all, powerful. A 12 character roster (technically 14) with their own unique active and passive abilties. Add to that a heap of "mutations" aka perks that can help you during your run, going from the run of the mill stuff like "Extra Health" to "Hit Bullets have a chance to recover instantly" can allow you to play around certain weapon types, making you the king of the wasteland. Though it may seem brutal at the start it gets a lot better once you get better at it. It's one of those games that you start a round of at 10pm, then end up at 3am and hating yourself for loving it. Absolutely reccomended, unless you hate shooters, hard games or roguelikes.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne is a fast paced top-down shooter with rogue-like elements.It takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where everything is out to get you, including crows with SMGs and rats. So many rats. This game is pretty hard but obviously the more you play the better you get and also the more knowledge you obtain to better your next run. There is a vast amount of weaponry from average pistols to poison grenade launchers and rifles that literally shoot lightning. An average Nuclear Throne run looks like this: To start, there is a flurry of bullets coming towards you. As you continue, you get better weapons but the enemies get stronger and shoot MORE bullets towards you. Every few levels, you find a boss that has considerably more health than everyone else, and seem to only spawn when you are in a pinch and surrounded by enemies.In short, this game has a surprising amount of story to it and the developers update it almost every week, not to mention the music is awesome and there are secret levels everywhere. What more could you ask for?

								I've been playing this game off-and-on for a couple of years now and it just keeps getting better. Vlambeer is a great studio and this may be my favorite game in their stellar line-up. Nuclear Throne is a shoot-em-up rogue-like where you battle for the throne in a post-apocalyptic wasteland.Paul Veers artwork is really something special and just getting to see his designs serves as plenty of motivation to progress to the next stage. content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												I bought this game a while ago and was very skeptical of throwing money at a unfinished game that looked promising but I like many of us have been burned before at the hype, smoke and mirrors style of game advertisers (the magician that takes your money and shows no magic).I went in skeptical and finished a true believer, this game PC MASTER RACE ( < elitist group think), this game is the absolute bombastic ♥♥♥♥♥♥ balls to the walls style chaotic shooting role playing experience. now I've hyped it I'll tell you the goods and badsUPDATE!!!!!!!!!the awesome.- The weaponage. so much thought and effort went into the weapon system, the developers obviously did their homework and listened to community feedback. There is a Tier weapon system that RNGs your loot, early on regular weapons of 5 different types of ammo will do. Later as the challenge builds you will find better weapons (some skills will boost specific weapons or help build a character e.g around a super auto crosbow) to spray the next battlefield and dodge like a ninja. Once you learn the secrets you can get hyper weapons which as robot means sweet nutrition and a skin. I got two portals to open giving me better gun tech on top of my passive ability, dodged the throne enough and obliterated it with my incredible power, skills and weaponage. all of which felt like a great triumph. yet theres so much more to learn.- Variational gameplay. meaning it's rng. different evertime but sweetly similar, the replayability jumps again at the number of different characters with different styles... I miss the chicken freeze time ability. but consitently you will get better weapons as the game gets harder. none of that binding of issac lame power ups as the game gets harder.- THE DIFFICULTY. It's hard, unforgiving like your parents when they caught you ♥♥♥♥♥♥ an apple pie, but that's a good thing because you learn from your mistakes and get better at♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the pie. which makes the expierence all the more rewarding. If you get caught with your pants down it is mainly your own fault-The Graphics.that perfect mix of low fi cartoon style but defined well that you can see all the detailed pixel art. there are points that the chaos is too much but that's hardly bad. they got rid of that crappy screen shake problem, and it all flows smoothly, like a waterfall of caramelly chocolate goodness and rainbows wrapped in ♥♥♥♥♥♥s straight into your eyeballs.- The charaters and Power upseach character has a unique special ability, all the characters are fun to play and add layers to a already big onion. there's a secret throne room that offers different crowns of game changing awesomeness. after you level you get a moment in the spining vortew to pick a perk that enhances your characters traits. there will always be atleast 2 good power ups for the type of character your building and it's fun to grow stronger as the game does. the difficulty is still tough but unless you can't handle the heat, the food your cookings tasty. - IT IS FUNalot of games miss that crucial component. it is fun, I've played alot of this game and it's still fun and I still haven't finished it cause that boss with the jetpack and crazy gun kills me so fast. one moment I'm a mutated fish rolling on the ground the next I'm a mutated fish NOT rolling on the ground. such a powerful image even a child could understand it.fun, so much fun it's the very definition of fun gameplayTHE♥♥♥♥♥♥br>- some small bugs, like the game wont start for me for some updates. but then it does. this is a minor issue and won't matter when they finish it. its still getting better and better. i hope it becomes the masterpiece it could potentially be- the tipsduring loading screens they give you tips, while some like "don't die" or "don't be afraid" are funny and even motivating to push yourself further. at some point there should be a deeper guide that you dont have to buy or search for seperately- the chickenneeds a better power up(it's much better now, still not my favourite but a cool character. Throwing your weapons to save ammo or in desperation is excellent and another example of the devs taking note)in summary buy this game because it's awesome and a great investment in time killing. even now with the early access it's worth twice the asking price.UPDATE!I FINISHED THIS MONSTOSITYconclusion is 40% learning from mistakes through masochistic dying. 10 % accuracey, concentration and dodging 10% concentrated power of will. 40% luck and funno replayability cause it was some guerilla warfare pain.UPDATE 2.0This is almost everything i wanted and i had high hopes. would like more secrets or DLC but well worth supporting it. I've played hundreds of hours and enjoyed every single one damn nearly. well done to the team that made this, well darn done.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I've destroyed bandit clans across the WasteslandsConquered the Sewers from rat and gatorDominated the Scrapyards with an iron fistBraved the Crystal CavesBrought heat into the Frozen CityOutmatched Lil Hunter in wits, skill, and firepowerSurvived the Labs and its hordes of abominationsDiscovered and razed the Palace within secondsMastered the weaponaryBecame one with the radiationAnd stood victorious among wreckage that once was the Nuclear ThroneOnly to be bludgeoned to death by a purple ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a stick10/10In all honesty, this game is just marvelous. Vicious, gritty, filled to brim with character and challenge and death. Some people may play games as a sort of therapy, but most will need it after wittnessing this masterpiece. Guns upon guns upon guns (with melee weapons), a good selection of classes from a roided-out scientist that can duel wield to a cute little robot that can eat guns for health and ammo. You will rage, you will cry, and you'll come back playing, because when you play Nuclear Throne, you live it. You aren't a person controlling the mutant, you are the mutant. You gain the urges, the lust, and the will to traverse outward on your bloody pilgrimage. To make things right, many must fall, including you, but take heart, and the stars will aline in your favor. Every night by the campfire, every gun you pick up, every foe that drops in your wake is one step closer to reaching...the Nuclear Throne.Let's do this.Edit: It is finally complete and I'm still coming back after a year of playing. I'm suprised to see that fish can still roll.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Before you drop your money on this game you need to be aware of something very, very important about Nuclear Throne: this is probably one of the most difficult and frustrating games you've ever encountered.I'm not giving this a thumbs-down because the game is terrible, it's a good game.  The graphics are lovely, the music is 10 out of 10, and it is enjoyable to play.  My thumbs-down is not me panning the game, I'm taking the "Do you recommend this game?" question literally and writing my review as a warning.  There comes a point when games are so excessively difficult that people need to be notified going in.  There's a very high chance that most people should avoid this game, because this game is designed to appeal to an extremely small audience: the highest tier of elite, hardcore, massively-skilled gamers.If you want an idea of what you're getting into, imagine one of the hardest games you've ever played, and then imagine if that game sent you back to the very beginning after the slightest mistake.  A bird in Ninja Gaiden knocks you into a pit? Back to level one.  Get hit by a single stray bullet in Contra?  Back to the title screen.  This game is about as difficult as trying to beat Mega Man without getting hit once.I was aware that this game was difficult when I bought it, because I love nightmarishly difficult shooters and roguelikes, and this game still was able to alienate me.  You can have a competitive, positive attitude about challenging games, and Nuclear Throne will still transform you into a ragequitter. There is no forgiveness, and there is no room for mistakes.  Nuclear Throne demands absolute perfection of you.  And this game doesn't play fair.Your health bar is pretty much irrelevant, because there are no invincibility frames upon getting hit.  You can have tons of HP upgrades, and a small cluster of bullets will destroy you inside of a split second.  There will always be something far off screen shooting extremely high speed projectiles at you, and your view is very zoomed in.  The screen is always violently shaking, and the game actually mocks you if you turn the screen shake "feature" off, as though your desire to make the game less of a jittery mess is somehow your fault.  Most enemies explode when you kill them. Sometimes it doesn't damage you and sometimes it... does?  Sometimes you'll die being sucked into the exit portal because it spawned next to an explosive object.  Sometimes the game will randomly generate a level where you are surrounded on all sides by enemies with no cover, and you're dead seconds after the level loads.You will be saying "what the hell even HIT me?" constantly while playing this game.  Even the best played runs will end because of the tiniest mistake.I'm certain that the sense of accomplishment upon beating this game is absolute euphoria.  And I'm very certain that there are gamers with superhuman reflexes that this game is like catnip to.  I will say that if you can beat this game, you are truly a phenomenal gamer.  I wouldn't laugh at you if you printed out a screenshot of you beating it and hung it on your wall; you've earned it.  If you are one of those people that is looking for the ultimatest of ultimate challenges, then this game is going to deliver in spades.But for the rest of us mortals, I recommend saving your money and your sanity.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Welcome to Nuclear Throne, and this is a review for it. As for now, Nuclear Throne is a early-access rogue-like indie game, that receives weekly updates to make the game more balanced and fun, as well as adding a lot of stuff. It still has loads of planned features, so if you decide to get the game, stick around it for a while, or come back to it from times to times to always have new experiences with it.Now starting from the game: You open the game to be welcomed by a very enjoyable soundtrack, as well as the character selection menu for it. You start the game with a few characters, but as you progress through it, you will unlock more of them, and at the time of this review, they are pretty easy to unlock. Every character has a passive and active ability, the active ability being used by pressing the right button of the mouse once in-game. It's also recommended you try every character, since they all play differently.Once you select a character, you are ready to go. You will find yourself with a weapon at hands, surrounded by enemies in the middle of a nuclear wasteland. Your objective is to use the weapons and abilities on your arsenal to kill all the enemies in the area to activate a portal, leading to the next level. You quest is to reach a throne, collecting radiation on your way to mutate yourself and turn into a even more powerful being, as well as collecting new weapons, which can be divided by:-Bullet weapons-Shell weapons-Bolt weapons-Explosive weapons-Energy weapons-Melee weapons(note that all the weapon types listed above have their own ammo, and also their own sub categories, but that use the same ammo type)The gameplay is very simple. You spawn in a area, filled with enemies, and the random generated levels could get you easily, so keep an eye open. Sometimes it could be very easy but in other occasions, it might just swarm you with foes, leaving you to die right after spawning. The game can also be frustrating at the time, since the chances of you being a master right off the start are very small, so you can expect to die a lot, but it's all part of the game, everytime you play it and die, you grow better at it for learning how to deal with enemies carefully. Keep an eye on your ammo, as you might run out pretty quickly with certain weapons, and don't forget to choose your mutations wisely.Wrapping everything up, I'd give Nuclear Throne a 10/10 for being an awesome game. Awesome soundtrack, challenging gameplay, and an frustrating, yet enjoyable, expirience. I'd recommend going to the game's Wiki[nuclear-throne.wikia.com] for more in-depth information about the game's development and already implemented features. Remember once again that the game might not be enjoyable right away for some people not used to this kind of game, rogue-likes tend to be difficult and require patience to play and master

												TL;DR: BUY THIS GAME.I really love this game!It's a fast paced roguelike shooter in which the goal is to get to the 'Nuclear Throne' by advancing through different randomly generated levels. I've only got about 2.3 hours into the game but I play it every day and I love it!All of the classes are nicely balancedI love the fact that you can watch Vlambeer's livestreams every Tuesday and Thursday where they add new contentI really like how the game itself is set up!I bought the predecessor 'Wasteland Kings' in the Mojam 2 Humble bundle, and found out about the improved version at the Indie Developer booth at Minecon :)I reccomend this game to anyone who has some money to spend on an awesome game!EDIT: It's been 6 months since I purchased the game and I do not regret it. There was a large gap of time in which I didn't play the game, but a couple of updates put me back into it. I've gotten around 11 hours into this game in 6 months, which isn't really that much because of the length of time that I have owned this game. Even though I'm absolutely horrible at this game and cannot get past Big Dog (the second boss) I still love it to death and won't stop playing it until the development stops on it. The devs really make this game awesome, doing livestreams for players to know that their hard-earned money has not gone to waste, sometimes going onto the livestreams of their community, actually responding to questions on the steam community hub, and doing constant updates. All of this stuff makes me want to play the game, be it because of the new content or just that I'm supporting awesome devs.EDIT 2: It's been more than a year and a half since I purchased the game. I only have 60 hours in it and suck but it's one of my favorite games. The devs are awesome and the game is great, it's worth your money. I definitely recommend it.EDIT 3: It's been more than two years since I have purchased this game, it has now been fully released. This game is definitely STILL WORTH IT, and I've enjoyed every minute of my playtime, even if most of my deaths were due to BS like Golden Snow Tanks. Verdict: BUY IT.

								Nuclear Throne feels complete to me, like, when I play it I don't find myself thinking 'wow that's shoddy' or 'they need to finish this bit' or anything, so the frequent updates that keep improving all aspects of the game are kind of eye-opening. content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												Part Rogue-like, Part RPG, part bullet-hell -- this game has a lot of charm and is quite addictive. Deceptively complex when you get down to the business of different levels and enemies and all the perks and weapon combinations you might use to prevail. I tried my darndest, but I could never win -- I'd gotten far, and I consider it a point of honor to win Rogue-likes that I love... but maybe someday I'll come back and try to beat it. In the meantime I had fun playing with multiple characters that actually play differently, and some great fun winning levels in crushing victory or by the skin of my teeth. Nuclear Throne, you have earned a place in my heart... a game that beat me, but I loved you anyway. <3

												Nuclear Throne is a fast and punchy roguelike shooter. It will rock your world, send you back in time before your world was rocked, and will proceed to rock it once more. This cycle will go on forever.Throwing hard-hitting sound effects, music, and bullets into your face and ears, Nuclear Throne is an endless assault on almost all of your senses.In the game, you will die not once, not twice, not even thrice. You will die a lot more than that. You will face challenges that mostly consist of bullets, and you will fail these challenges.You touch the carpet. Something happens.You hit Retry and start over.
