content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Nuclear throne is hands down one of my favorite games. Playing it throughout all the updates, changes, and bug fixes is like watching someone grow up. It might be a challenging game at first, but if you keep on practicing and never give up hope of reaching the throne, you'll be brandishing golden weapons and looping in no time. Now, the price of this game while it is still in early access might scare away some people, but the game hardly has any bugs, and any error that is reported will most likely be fixed in the weekly updates. BUTif you give up/get angry easily and have trouble learning from mistakes, I do not reccomend this game. If you die, you DO start over from the begginging. There are no save points, no permanent unlocks (yet), and NO MERCY.So yes, I do reccomend Nuclear Throne to those who can handle it. Vlambeer has created another 8-bit bullet hell masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								As someone who played the original Wasteland Kings, finally being able to afford this game and play through it is like a dream come true. I'm completely awed at how far this game has come, and I could not be any more pleased with what I've played.You get dropped in a post-apocalyptic nuclear wasteland as a mutant with nothing but a revolver and a dream. And huge mobs of freaky♥♥♥♥♥creatures, robots, bandits, and everything else that you probably wouldn't want to encounter in a wasteland. All to get a piece of that sweet sweet throne.This game is an arcade style top down shoot 'em up, with different characters to pick from and randomized maps and guns, so no two runs are never the same. You will need to learn what works and what gets you killed faster than that assassin that you didn't see that just ran up behind you and ended your attempt. Now you know to stay on your toes. This game is unforgiving, and brutally unfair. But that's what makes it fun. There's no hand holding. It's all you.This game is being constantly updated, tweaked, and improved. It's already endless fun. Vlambeer has created one of the absolute best games on Steam. I would highly, HIGHLY, SO FREAKING HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who loves brutal, fast paced action, explosions, and that kind of motivating frustration that makes you say "Oh yeah? I'll show you, I'll beat this game next run!"

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne is an indie rouguelike-ish game, but i would consider it a hack'n'slash game. Eventhough it's still in early access , the game seems complete, Vlambeer, the devs are updating the game every week.So, let's get right into the review!=======Story/Lore=======The story isn't the main focus of the game, it's pretty basic, but later compensated by the gameplay and graphics styleHere you have some of the story:Earth became a nuclear wasteland, after some time, humans and other organic organisms started mutating, they've grown stronger, with the hability to use guns and other stuff, the game's main objective is to reah the "Nuclear Throne"there's not much to it :S=======Gameplay=======Well, as i pinted out on the start, it's a fast paced rouguelike game where you have a variety of characters and weapons to choose, you go trhogh stages, defeat bosses, and do loops, it's a top-down shooter.=======Music=======The music amd sound effects for this game are simply amazing, composed by JUKIO KALLIO and JOONAS TURNER really stuned me, its great music, in my opinion it's way better than som AAA games out there.=======Art/Graphics=======All Vlambeer games have the same art style, nuclear throne isn't an exeption, the animations are smooth, the game looks beautiful.=======Final Veredict=======08/10It's a game defnitly worth buying. it's extremely funny!-xoxo Kyozumo, btw, if Vlambeer is reading this, i came from Mcswift101

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Nuclear Throne is a fast paced shooter. I feel that it's a cross between a twin-stick shooter and The Binding of Isaac. It is a hard, but addicting game that rewards you the more time you spend honing your skills. Yes, some of your level spawns can ruin your run, but it's mostly player error. If you like a challenge, this game is for you. It's not Dark Souls difficult, but some days it can feel that way. I have logged many hours into the game, and yet to tire of it. I am gaining skill with each character, and what guns and mutations work best with them.

content:

Early Access Review
								I couldn't recommend this game without saying one thing. It's friggin' awesome. For a cheap title, it's a hell lotta' fun.For one, it's filled with a ton of characters with various risks vs. rewards and ultimately takes a ton of skill, time, and effort to find your best character, playstyle, and luck, of course! Go full dakka as Steroids? Or equip yourself with a melee and a weapon for some more utility? Ultimately, it comes down to preference. The art so far for this game is amazing. The music is great, rememberable, something that you wouldn't mind listening to outside of playing it. Enemy design is great, easy to follow patterns, but when the going gets tough, it gets tough.

Though the two are alike there are huge differences for Nuclear Throne.  For example In  Nuclear Throne you collect rads.  At the end of each level if you collected enough rads to level up you get to choose a mutation.  These help you get through the proggresivly harder levels.  There are a lot of secrets and and each is different and unique from the last.  Some secrets get you new characters or unlock new guns or skins for previous characters.  Over all this is an amazing game recommended for all, by AMERICA. It gets the AMERICAN review of 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Easily one of my favorite games of all times. I'm a big fan of rogue-likes but, until now, I have not really been a big fan of bullet hell games. The game is exciting from the first second, the action is fast and chaotic, and the difficulty ramps up steadily. Each run can last anywhere from a couple of minutes to 30+ minutes. It takes seconds to randomly generate a new floor so it keeps you in the action and always keeps you guessing. The entire environment is destructable so using explosive weapons, destroying certain objects, or enemies can greatly change the landscape of a floor. That along with the corpses staying on the floor, by the end of the 3-4 minute long floor, it really looks like a huge battle had just occurred. On the surface, the characters may seem pretty similar considering most of them all start with the same weapon, have the same movement speed, have the same amount of HP, and can hold the same number of weapons. Once you spend a couple of hours with a character you realize how unique they actually are and how easily you can create some pretty unique character builds by applying new mutations. Mutations are earned after reaching a new character level and can greatly enhance or modify the single run you are on. Mutations range from higher max HP and max ammo, to modifying weapons, to more utility based like allowing you to break through walls. A ton of secrets, easter eggs, and unlocks are scattered throughout the game. Bosses are challenging and fun. Mini-bosses and stronger variations of common enemies tend to spawn periodically on certain floors to keep you on your toes. There are a TON of weapons to find in random drops and random chests. Each weapon is unique and has it's own pros and cons. This makes it more interesting and there are very few instances where one gun is a hands-down upgrade over another gun because a more powerful version may have a slower fire-rate or consume a lot more ammo. Nuclear Throne is addicting, exciting, super fast-paced, and amazing fun. I currently have over 200 hours on record and don't anticipate ending that anytime soon. Highly recommended to people who enjoy shooters, bullet hells, rogue-likes, and fast-paced games in general. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								I would not have thought in 2014 I'd be able to spend much time at all on a simplistic shoot-em-up, but here I am.  This game finds elegance in its simplicity reminiscent of Hotline Miami, along with the same capacity for interesting emergent strategy, and the solidly visceral feel that comes from individually subtle but carefully-put-together cues adding up nicely.  Throw on top of that the infinite novelty of the procedural death labyrinth format and the light semi-randomized RPG elements, and you have a timesuck on the scale of roguelike games, but that will keep your adrenaline up the whole time.  The game even has a few rush mechanics to keep the action flowing, without resorting to anything as ham-fisted or annoying as a timer.  The music is also excellent for setting that fast-paced, deadly, slightly-creepy mood.

								This is ridiculously good action packed dual stick rouge like shooter!!11!11one111This game is exceptional in many ways but one of them is the unevitability of horrible death, for most of us before reaching the Nuclear Throne. The game is so hard and rage inducing, I need to learn it over multiple days... I played thousands of videogames so I'm kinda surprised this one motivates me enough to put in so much effort... I'm impressed. - Amazing pixel graphics. - Smooth dual stick controls. - Beautiful map generator. - Map awarenes required to survive. - Mad skill cap. - Colorful characters. - Crazy Weapons. - The amazing portal animation with fancy words of wisdom.Note that I enjoy the game on xbox controller and I wouldn't bother with ridiculously accurate mouse and keyboard.At the time of writing - if I should reccommend a single videogame to a player who enjoys challenge, it would be Nuclear Throne. Best blind buy ever.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												UPDATED 1.0 REVIEW:First let us look back to my review on August 26th 2014!---Alpha based review: Just like their previous games Vlambeer hits the nail on it's head by once again giving the player INSTANT satisfaction, on easy to LEARN, but hard to MASTER gameplay. This all nicely shown in a pixel art style that representative, fun and appealling.---New review:First off: This is one of the best Early Acces game releases, probably the best. With their mentality to really get everything out of EA they went and did it. Every Tuesday and Thursday on of the team was streaming: showing new projects in the developent, streaming the game, having fun with new ideas, testing new features, answering questions. They have truelly been an inspiration for me in the past 1.5 years I have followed them develop this game. We were able to see it from beginning to end and we got delivered what they were promised.The Good:- The game play: it's fast and fun- Instant gratification: Jump right into the action, no bla bla. (If you get the joke, well done).Lot's of characters, weapons and MUTATIONS: so many combinations to try out, you keep combining and you have to, as everything is randomly found.- Good challenge: If you're not a very skilled player, this game is still fun, you will still have a feeling of achievement after ending a run. For the high skilled: try staying alive when you are looped! More bosses, more environments, harder enemies!- Audio: The reason I bought the game. The rough sounds gives a tough feel, a super attitude to a game that oozes with action. Every gun feels better.- Price: €12,99, that's not pricey for a single/co-op game.The Bad: - Crashes: Game crashes when immediately leaving the co-op menu, after entering.- Stats: Stats do not load.The Ugly:- Some graphic bugs: Shovel looks weird, sometimes a glitch.Conclusion:I highly recommend this game, if you like top down shooters, guns blazing, rough audio, a cool soundtrack and EXPLOSIONS! So much fun and hard to get through. You'll easily get you money out of it! Thanks JW + Rami (Vlambeer) and team.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												Nuclear Throne is a fantastic Rogue-Like top down shooter, with 12 different characters to play as, and a very huge assortment of weapons to find and choose from! I genuinely enjoy this game, it's just fantastic and absorbs you slowly from the inside out. My favorite character, Steroids, has the special ability to hold and fire two weapons which leads to very insane and fun runs. Every character has their own passives and actives such as Crystal's ability to shield and Fish can roll, leaving lots of opportunities for very fun and interesting runs. My only two complaints would be that while there is indeed co-op, it's limited to being on the same computer which isn't very fun in my opinion due to most of my friends who play NT live elsewhere. My other complaint would be the lack of modding allowed in the most recent versions of the game, which in my opinion would make the game WAY more fun and with huge amounts of variety.But despite those downfalls, it's still a fantastic game worth your rightfully earned money. Will you reach the Nuclear Throne?There is no yeti.

												One of the best games i ever played, imagine Binding of isaac with guns, Explosions and a Nuclear Apocalypse. Play it with Mouse and keyboard, with Controller it's really hard to Play.I think i needed around 50 Hours before my first Loop, and it only gets better and better,                                                               it feels absolutely awesome if you beat Big Dog, Lil Hunter or the Throne for the first Time.The game has 14 Characters, and a lot of Weapons seperated into Bullet, Shell, Energy, Explosive, Bolt and Melee Categories. You level up by Collecting Radiation, if you have enough, you are presented with a set of 4 different Mutations, with effects like "Longer Melee range" or "More item Drops".I really enjoy the Graphics, both the Character Art and the Sprites. If you want to see more gameplay,Go watch somebody on Youtube, like Sleepcycles (https://www.youtube.com/user/sleepcyclesgaming),Chubbyemu (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKOvOaJv4GK-oDqx-sj7VVg) or the current world record holder Horheristo (https://www.youtube.com/user/horheristo), i really enjoyed their gameplay Videos.Just pay those 12 Dollars, it's Definetly worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												Recommend Nuclear Throne is not an easy task, you must first recognize if you have a deeper problem of compulsive masochism, if you like to suffer, this is your game.Nuclear throne is a shooter with overhead view and Roguelike elements such as randomly generated scenarios, economy inventory and high difficulty, in which we have to shoot everything that looks like a threat (a "Shoot and then asks" full-fledged). For this purpose we use an absurd amount of weapons (+100) which are as useful as multifarious (guitars, lasers rays, bazookas, crossbows, etc.) and a concept called "Mutation", which is a type of modifier which is activated when you level up your character; there are all kinds of modifiers such as increasing life points, make enemies drop more likely to make or increase shooting accuracy, to name a few.Nuclear Throne have a lot of charismatic characters with different intrinsic skills; Crystal is a piece of purple quartz whose special ability is activate a shield that bounces from enemy bullets for 2 seconds, Steroids can use dual weapons or Chicken and his ability to throw their weapons at enemies.The main virtue of Nuclear Throne lies in the constant randomness and our ability to adapt to these situations, sometimes in the less pleasant ways and perhaps an unfair randomness in some sections, but never fault the game itself but rather by the failed approach we give to our plays. Our mission is to reach and defeat the Nuclear Throne, yes, but much matter how, the weapons I have, the mutations I have chosen, the character I'm playing, the arrangement and number of enemies and obstacles on stage. Everything under the halo of a subconscious immutable fluidity and rigor that enables playing with almost no major surprises to a true bullet hell situations.Perhaps Nuclear Throne is the highest point of Vlambeer as video game developer and in which their dual philosophy of direct fun and almost obscene depth is clearly note, it is a game that can end in 5 minutes, or get stuck for hours trying to discover new weapons, situations, enemies, characters, etc.Nuclear Throne is hard drug, so beware.___________________________________________________________________________________En español:Recomendar Nuclear Throne no es tarea sencilla, primeramente hay que reconocer si tienes un profundo problema de masoquismo compulsivo, si te gusta sufrir, este es tu juego. Nuclear throne es un shooter de vista cenital con elementos Roguelike tales como escenarios generados aleatoriamente, economía de inventario  y dificultad elevada, en el cual tenemos que dispararle a todo lo que se parezca a una amenaza (Un “Dispara y después pregunta” en toda regla). Para este fin nos valemos de una cantidad absurda de armas (+100) las cuales son tan útiles como variopintas (guitarras, rayos lasers, bazookas, ballestas, etc) y de un concepto llamado “Mutacion”, el cual consiste en un tipo de modificador el cual se activa al subir de nivel a nuestro personaje; hay todo tipo de modificadores tales como aumentar los puntos de vida, Hacer que los enemigos hagan drop con mayor probabilidad o aumentar la precisión de tiro, por citar algunos.En Nuclear Throne tenemos a unos personajes carismáticos y con diferentes habilidades intrínsecas; Crystal es un pedazo de Cuarzo morado que tiene como habilidad especial activar un escudo que hace rebotar las balas enemigas por 2 segundos, Steroids que puede usar armas duales o Chicken y su capacidad de lanzar sus armas a los enemigos. La principal virtud de Nuclear Throne reside en la aleatoriedad constante y en nuestra CAPACIDAD de adaptarnos a esas situaciones, a veces de las maneras menos placenteras y quizás con una aleatoriedad injusta en algunos tramos, pero nunca por fallo del propio videojuego sino más bien por el acercamiento fallido que le damos a nuestras partidas. Nuestra misión es llegar y derrotar al Trono Nuclear, sí, pero importa mucho el cómo, las armas que llevo, las mutaciones que he elegido, el personaje con el que estoy jugando, el arreglo y cantidad de los enemigos y obstáculos en el escenario. Todo bajo el inmutable halo de una fluidez subconciente y con el rigor que posibilita una partida sin casi mayores sobresaltos a verdaderos infiernos de balas. Quizás Nuclear Throne sea el punto más alto de Vlambeer como desarrolladora de videojuegos y en el cual se nota evidentemente esa filosofía dual de diversión directa y profundidad casi obscena, es un juego que puedes acabar en 5 minutos que tengas o quedarte atrapado por horas tratando de descubrir nuevas armas, situaciones, enemigos, personajes.Nuclear Throne es droga dura, así que, cuidado.(La heroina de los Ludopatas) xD

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Previously I made a negative review for this game. When I was writing that review I failed to notice that even though each update comes with a new bug, it also comes with a new feature. This is one of the reasons Nuclear Throne is such an amazing game, and it's simply because the dev team truely cares for it. It's a game focused around having a bullet for every inch of your screen, but who cares. The insane gameplay gives no time to rest as you are forced to each level in an infinite loop constantly finding better loot, and harder enemies. The game takes a while to learn, and it will be a good week before you even reach the frozen city, or big dog, but when you do it's the best feeling in the world. Nuclear Throne features a huge roster of characters that have no gimmicks that force you into a certain gamestyle, but rather unique features that you can addapt within your own game style. (Instead of doing more melee damage and less gun damage slo mo) The game never seems to punish you for exploring a new game style and instead seems to encourage that there truely isn't a meta and that you must discover your own. Sadly the free copy of the game I recieved was given to someone who has ill taste for these sorts of games but even with that he still had a hell of a lot of fun. Overall it's a game that even with it's bugs, is so much fun it's easy to ignore. Easy 10 outta 10

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												Nuclear Throne is the classic rogue-lite structure but somehow made into a fair challenge, despite the random number gods still being omnipotentAny strategy is viable, as long as you can think fast and dodge well. There is no terrible mutation choice or gun to use, even the lowly screwdriver gives you the chance to turn Kenshiro on enemies!Although I have some gripes about certain enemies, mainly some being a little too meaty in health, I still feel like I'm doing consistent damage and progressing, I've never felt like I was at a brick wall in terms of progression due to bad weapon drops, which I really appreciate.In short, absolutely recommended to those that want to enjoy the classic Twin-stick style of games with more variety and far more hectic action added!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								A fun, fast paced game that relies more on one's own skill rather than items gotten like The Binding of Isaac.  Not saying Isaac is a bad game though, this one's deaths feel more fair and more of "I couldn't help it" instead of "This game didn't give me the items I needed".  I say, for the price it is and it having multiplayer as well, get it because its fun and worth it.  Be warned though, it is a VERY difficult game and requires multiple playthroughs to get good at it and there is no ending to the game when you beat it, instead it loops back to the start.  Take the looping aspect as you will, its a difficult game but worth the pain.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game updates frequently enough to keep people coming back for more. Although it is challenging and still in development, this game is very fun to play. I find myself playing through the game, dying, raging, dropping the game for about 15 minutes, and then coming back for more punishment.It's highly randomized maps make for a new experience every time you play. The mutations the characters can receive gives this game something different for each playthrough.Doing a quick run-through of this game may seem like there isn't much to it; however, on closer inspection and certain conditions, the game reveals hidden areas and new combos that allow for even more enjoyment.The developers are very involved in the Steam community and reply to ideas and threads about the game. The obviously care enough about the game and its development to make it stand out.I could debate whether or not this game is actually a "rogue-like" game, but it does have certain qualities like "minimalistic" graphics (the graphics are detailed, but pixelated), randomability, and dungeon crawl like maps. It also has a wide selection of characters that a player can use.This game is in development, but it sure is a gem so far.Get this game. You will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fast, fun and frequently updated. Nuclear Throne is highly replayable and satisfying.The enemies are varied, the guns each feel different and there's a decent level of strategy over randomness with weapon, mutation and character selection. It feels quite balanced, even whilst in early access, and Vlambeer tweak and update the game on a very frequent schedule (about weekly, so far as I have seen).There is the promise of eventual online co-op and perhaps a versus mode too, but even without those I would recommend the game.

content:

Early Access Review
								Fast, fun and frequently updated. Nuclear Throne is highly replayable and satisfying.The enemies are varied, the guns each feel different and there's a decent level of strategy over randomness with weapon, mutation and character selection. It feels quite balanced, even whilst in early access, and Vlambeer tweak and update the game on a very frequent schedule (about weekly, so far as I have seen).There is the promise of eventual online co-op and perhaps a versus mode too, but even without those I would recommend the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Nuclear Throne is a blast+All characters are diverse and fun. 9 of the 12 playable characters fill up my #1 favourite character slot.+Neat graphics. The graphics in NT don't have pixel art because the designers were lazy. Enemy and character designs are very simple but all look extremely polished. The art is very loveable, over the top, hilarious and stunning.+Many weapons to experiment with, master and have a good time with. Whether you use grenade launchers to laser pistols to triple-frikin-machine guns, there's something here you will love.+Fun upgrades to try out when you level up which makes the game even more hectic.+The music is a wonderful experience. The tunes range from something that makes you feel on a joyride or killing spree to the quiet gritiness of a sewer to the post apocalyptic emptiness of the game's environment.  +The manliness, colour and personality of everything. The most noticable thing is the screenshake that makes you feel like the manliest man in history as you shoot everything in the face. Some other cool little things are the mysterious short worded phrases and tips in the loading screens, the different cute languages that each mutant and their enemies speak and the alternate skins that some characters have that are really smart. Heck, even the XP in the game are called "rads" (short for radiation).+Did I mention the co-op? It's great. Co-op relies mostly on teamwork and it works very well with the NT formula. However, there are times when if you die, you will have to wait a while for either your friend to die or be revived. This can be an annoyance so it is best to play NT with a buddy that has about equal skill level with you.+-Great for those who love a challenge. I'm warning you lighthearted gamers out there, this game is TOUGH. Health and ammo resources are limited, enemies are cunning and are in large packs and you will usually die forever in 2-3 hits. With almost 16 hours of play, I have pathetically not reached the throne (final area) yet. However, similarly in games like Spelunky, you will learn from most of your deaths an you will improve very quickly.In summary, NT is an excellent roguelike that you should defintely add to your library. It has fun gameplay, loveable art and music with tons of personality and it will keep you content for hundreds of hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												One of the best love hate relationships you'll ever have with a video game. Having done everything this game has to offer, this game will go down as one of the most difficult, but most rewarding games ever. Every feat makes you feel accomplished. Reaching the throne, killing the throne, killing throne 2, the list goes on. As you get better those rewarding moments will become cakewalks. Where the real joy comes into play is knowing each enemies patterns, knowing which skills go best for your characters. Amazing weapons where you will find your favorites quickly based on your play style. When it comes to fast pace, addicting gameplay you can't do much better than nuclear throne. The throne is calling for you. Accept the charges. Enjoy and git gud!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								An entertaining hybrid of shmup and rpg tied together with reasonably diverting fluff and art.  The combination of shoot'n'dodge and character builder really emphasizes the complexity and importance of decision-making.   I like it.  It's a game to play with music pumping and wanting to get pumped up in 10 minutes- if you can make it even one play through.  I'd almost say it's an excellent lunchbreak speed-game in the sense of Strange Adventures in Infinite Space.  Semi-spoilers ah.. it's obvious that the draw is long-lasting complexity and high-skill ceiling, not tweests, right?The shooting and movement is very well-executed.  Combined with the screen shake, the experience is intense and embracing.   The situations you find yourself in vary a great deal, a consequence of weapon variety, enemy attack types, and  character's and talents.Balance, particularly for talents, is beta from my perspective.  I've been playing YV and Steroids, who both feature high-dps and emphasis on weapon combos, which could color my opinion.    The playstyle varies quite a bit between characters due to a variety of unique characteristics.  If I were better at dodging, I might prefer characters that are required to dodge more bullets due to comparatively low dps and talents that do little to shorten or ease a fight or improve my ability to panic spam.  Many of those heroes have traits that improve their resources.  Anyway, it is beta and balance is indisuptably a work in progress.A significant example of the design philosophy is the cursed weapons available at this time.  If you pick them up, you can only exchange them for other cursed weapons.  You get more ammo for those weapons though.  This is a principle that pervades the game; even though talents are never generally bad, they are very often situationally useless.  What good is  a bonus to energy weapon damage or kinetic ammo supply if you don't have those weapons?    Optimization in specific utility (for short-term survival or situations that are not sustainable or easily achievable) or for general viability of your build are very important and I'd hazard most players will spent some time at the inter-level level screen, simple as it is.It was worth it at $12 for me, but if you want it for less, it won't go on sale until after release.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												Very weighty combat, interesting setting and characters as well as various secrets to unlock. A 'rogue-lite' that relies more on player skill than RNG, instead of The Binding of Isaac think along the lines of Rogue Legacy in terms of skill Vs luck. Enemies and characters are designed very well, but depending on your taste the visual style may be lacking. Be aware going in that the game is difficult but is rarely unfair. This is definitely one of my favourites in the 'rogue-lite' genre, the soundtrack is also very good.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
 Review for Nuclear Throne  Pros:      - Challenging     - Amazing Pixel Work     - Unique Characters and Abilities     - Very Addicting Cons:      - "YOU DID NOT REACH THE NUCLEAR THRONE!" Summary Nuclear Throne is a very fun, quirky, fast-paced dungeon crawler that requires you to have quick reflexes and a sharp eye to reach your ultimate goal of taking a seat on the throne. Vlambeer have definately outdone themselves this time, as Nuclear Throne is one of the best games to ever hit Steam. With quick gameplay, excellently made sprites and  challenging enemies, Nuclear Throne is a must play game and is a brillaint way to pass the time. Vlambeer is also dedicated to updating the game every week so there is always something new to experience, and you can be sure that bugs will be removed swiftly. Even if you are tired of doing the same thing over and over, you can increase the difficulty by selecting different game changers (Crowns) that change the way you'll play the game.Sure there are a few bugs in the game, but every game has them and sure, the game can eventually get repetitive, but so does every game. And you can easily adjust the difficulty by selecting different crowns. Conclusion  To conclude this review, I would definately recommend buying Nuclear Throne if you are looking for something different and want a good challenge.

Posted: December 24, 2015
												My friend lent me this game still havent bought it cause im broke but if i could recomend this game your sure as hell I will. I have been playing since update 80ish im guessing but in that time that i have been playing it, ive gotten so attached to it that ill get home everyday and just go run after run after run. Even with all of its glitches and frezes its a quallity game and people should know about this game and how good it is.The game itself is a game that has a learning curve and is quiet difficult to get down (since there are like 10+ characters that all have different actives and passives). The thing is that most of it is down to the RNG of the game. One run you can have the best drops in the game and you loop like 3 time and you feel good about it. Then the next run comes and you die to lil' hunter cause of how bad it was.One bad thing is that every update there is at least one thing wrong with the game. The next update comes out and its fixed but something else is broke... but thats fine. It runs and you can play it thats all that matters. Honestly Nuclear Throne would be a 10/10 but that one problem that comes up gives it a solid                                                                                       9/10 get this game.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												I tend to repel against indie titles because most have pixelated graphics, a style I never quite enjoyed looking at. So after I finally lowered my biased opinion for once I saw a game called nuclear throne. Intrigued by it's similar gameplay like "The binding of isaac" which I enjoyed quite a bit, I bought the game after countless hesitations and started it up the moment it was done downloading.Man was this a breath of fresh air. This game to me was like Jesus freaking christ showing up to christian people. I never thought I would say "This is harder than trying to sing the russian national anthem backwards without even having heard it nor the russian language once" but here I am. If you're a fan of any rouge-like games whatsoever, then this game will certainly fulfill your dreams and beyond.   The gameplay is fast, hard it will probably end pretty quick (Like me in bed) because you died but you will want to start over again because it's so addictive.  The enemies will tear you apart, Your weapons will most likely screw you over in one way or another and if that's not enough the bosses will surely leave a scar on your back saying "i was here you lil shet."The music is bloody brilliant and fills you with adrenaline, actually helping you getting through the harsh level. Even there is little to no story to be discovered in the game there are bits and pieces which the player can make his/her/it's own conclusion to what the story is about.I think this game is great. Actually no, scratch that. I think this game sets the bar for how a difficult but fair game should be. Not a complete pounding session but a pounding session with some lube. And maybe some baby powder.Also fish can roll.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Nuclear Throne is one of the most spectacular games I've ever played.The game itself is satisfying, fun, atmospheric, and ever 150 hours in, I keep finding things I've never seen before. It requires skill, but also integrates an element of randomness, and you could play this game thousands of times and it would never get old.There is extreme variety, so that the game never seems repetitive. As you progress through each run, your character develops a playstyle of his/her own, based off of their respective mutations and weapons.This game has provided me with some harrowing and awesome moments, many of which kill me, but the few I get past give me an extreme sense of gratification.It is also one of the few games I actually enjoy watching someone else play.I would reccomend this game to pretty much anyone.

And although I have not reached most of what the game has to offer because I am terrible at the game I know it is there and can not wait to get there.TL;DR This game stands as a light in the murky sea of Rouge-Likes.

 Review for Nuclear Throne  Pros:      - Challenging     - Amazing Pixel Work     - Unique Characters and Abilities     - Very Addicting Cons:      - "YOU DID NOT REACH THE NUCLEAR THRONE!" Summary Nuclear Throne is a very fun, quirky, fast-paced dungeon crawler that requires you to have quick reflexes and a sharp eye to reach your ultimate goal of taking a seat on the throne. Vlambeer have definately outdone themselves this time, as Nuclear Throne is one of the best games to ever hit Steam. With quick gameplay, excellently made sprites and  challenging enemies, Nuclear Throne is a must play game and is a brillaint way to pass the time. Vlambeer is also dedicated to updating the game every week so there is always something new to experience, and you can be sure that bugs will be removed swiftly. Even if you are tired of doing the same thing over and over, you can increase the difficulty by selecting different game changers (Crowns) that change the way you'll play the game.Sure there are a few bugs in the game, but every game has them and sure, the game can eventually get repetitive, but so does every game. And you can easily adjust the difficulty by selecting different crowns. Conclusion  To conclude this review, I would definately recommend buying Nuclear Throne if you are looking for something different and want a good challenge.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												The game that manages best to fill the player with adrenaline to such an extent that you might even faint. So be ready for the absolute carnage and obliteration of everything on your screen(given you're good enough not to die on the first floors, because the game doesn't pull many punches) and for the bullet-hell-like situation you'll find yourself in as you play more and more. Nuclear Throne is very easy to pick up, it has extremely fast sessions(depending on how fast you go, or how fast you die, obviously) and it is the perfect game for someone who just wants to blow everything/everyone(even him/herself) up. While it doesn't have a detailed story, it still has some snippets here and there from which a person could come up with his own theory(though very limited, I must admit). It has a wide variety of weapons, characters, mutations(level-ups) and secrets. All in all, the game offers hours of fun and it's not hard to get into.

content:

 Review for Nuclear Throne  Pros:      - Challenging     - Amazing Pixel Work     - Unique Characters and Abilities     - Very Addicting Cons:      - "YOU DID NOT REACH THE NUCLEAR THRONE!" Summary Nuclear Throne is a very fun, quirky, fast-paced dungeon crawler that requires you to have quick reflexes and a sharp eye to reach your ultimate goal of taking a seat on the throne. Vlambeer have definately outdone themselves this time, as Nuclear Throne is one of the best games to ever hit Steam. With quick gameplay, excellently made sprites and  challenging enemies, Nuclear Throne is a must play game and is a brillaint way to pass the time. Vlambeer is also dedicated to updating the game every week so there is always something new to experience, and you can be sure that bugs will be removed swiftly. Even if you are tired of doing the same thing over and over, you can increase the difficulty by selecting different game changers (Crowns) that change the way you'll play the game.Sure there are a few bugs in the game, but every game has them and sure, the game can eventually get repetitive, but so does every game. And you can easily adjust the difficulty by selecting different crowns. Conclusion  To conclude this review, I would definately recommend buying Nuclear Throne if you are looking for something different and want a good challenge.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Nuclear Throne is a rouge-like bullet hell shooter that's as fun to play as it is difficult. There's a lot of chaos that goes on during fights and it can get pretty hectic. Never has it felt more great to feel your controller rumble to the hits you place on enemies. You will die, a lot in this game. But that's what makes it so fun to play. You want to get better and reach new areas in hopes that you will reach the nuclear throne.There are many characters to choose, each having their own strengths. Fish can roll, which makes for getting out of tight spots while Melting--the weakest of the bunch, can set off huge explosions. I personally love Fish due to his roll ability and Crystal--who can block attacks for a limited time. I do have to say that these unique abilites don't completely change the way you play with these characters, so it's a bit disappointing on that front. Nuclear Throne's main hook is mutation. After exiting a level, you can choose a mutation (assuming you have enough Rads) which can range from having an extra life to faster reload times to reducing enemy HP. Even though these mutations aren't permanent you do feel a sense of progression as you fight your way from level to level. From a visual standpoint, it looks pretty great, though many won't like that it's a locked 30fps game. My only gripe with this game is the lack of online play. Seriously, it's such a missed opportunity. I would love to play with people via online co-op. Overall, I really like Nuclear Throne and really recommend the game. Enjoy the fustration. Enjoy the chaos. But more importantly, good luck reaching the Nuclear Throne!

												Nuclear Throne is one of the most spectacular games I've ever played.The game itself is satisfying, fun, atmospheric, and ever 150 hours in, I keep finding things I've never seen before. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Jesus ♥♥♥♥ where to begin...Nuclear throne is one of those games where you WILL have a love/hate relationship.Love it for its characters, setting, fantastic soundtrack, bosses and butt-ton of weapons,and hate it for its brutal difficulty and the occasional area where good runs go to die (im looking at you crystal caves).So, lets get into it shall we?Nuclear throne is a roguelike shooter set in a post-apocalyptic world filled with mutants, freaks and everything inbetween. You play as a rhag-tag band of mutants, all filled with character and personality. These mutants dream of placing their mutant butts on the nuclear throne, a myth thats believed by these guys. These mutants are special, because as soon as they die, they get teleported back by these mystical portals popping up across the wasteland.The story is simple, you choose a mutant, and you travel across the many lands filled with a variety of freaks, bandits and  floating ♥♥♥♥ing crystals. In every main area (Badlands, scrapyard Etc) you'll encounter a boss that you must slay in order to go to the sub areas (Not the official name, but something I call them). These are areas that are inbetween the ordinary, 3 level areas. These are 1 level areas that are completely different in setting to other areas and hold special enemies and loot.After doing all of this (Trust me, its a long task) and doing specific things related to things I cant say due to spoilers, you can loop. This means going aaaaaall the way back to the start, but this time its harder, much, much harder. The enemies are tougher and theres a whole new cast of bosses to slay, each one harder than the last. The loot is better, but the risk is bigger.The way collectibles go, there are B-skins for every playable mutant, unlockable by doing specific things, some hard, some are very easy. There are also crowns to unlock through playing, this is essentially run modifiers that you can aquire mid way through the run or at the beginning. They add an extra challenge for the seasoned veteran. There are also golden guns that replace some of the original guns. These special versions are found in a certain area(s) and increase certain stats of the weapon or doing specific things. content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Nuclear Throne is a rouge-like bullet hell shooter that's as fun to play as it is difficult. There's a lot of chaos that goes on during fights and it can get pretty hectic. Never has it felt more great to feel your controller rumble to the hits you place on enemies. You will die, a lot in this game. But that's what makes it so fun to play. You want to get better and reach new areas in hopes that you will reach the nuclear throne.There are many characters to choose, each having their own strengths. Fish can roll, which makes for getting out of tight spots while Melting--the weakest of the bunch, can set off huge explosions. I personally love Fish due to his roll ability and Crystal--who can block attacks for a limited time. I do have to say that these unique abilites don't completely change the way you play with these characters, so it's a bit disappointing on that front. Nuclear Throne's main hook is mutation. After exiting a level, you can choose a mutation (assuming you have enough Rads) which can range from having an extra life to faster reload times to reducing enemy HP. Even though these mutations aren't permanent you do feel a sense of progression as you fight your way from level to level. From a visual standpoint, it looks pretty great, though many won't like that it's a locked 30fps game. My only gripe with this game is the lack of online play. Seriously, it's such a missed opportunity. I would love to play with people via online co-op. Overall, I really like Nuclear Throne and really recommend the game. Enjoy the fustration. Enjoy the chaos. But more importantly, good luck reaching the Nuclear Throne!

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												This game will require much from you. It will not relent, it will not hold your hand. Yet for the noble warrior who can tame its maddening trials, great glory awaits. This game brings me back to my early gaming days, playing Ghouls'n Ghosts (SNES) over and over without a save file and enduring through hours of restarts and near misses. Complete with an authentic old- school graphics style and tough but fair difficulty curve, it is pretty much the ultimate modern- day arcade shooter. Unlike the low- res games of yore, however, Nuclear Throne has randomly generated levels, randomly dropping weapons and randomly selected skills to enjoy along your journey. This is a game of skill, strategy, and white- knuckle reflexes. And pain. Lots and lots of pain.Vlambeer, you've done it again.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Jesus ♥♥♥♥ where to begin...Nuclear throne is one of those games where you WILL have a love/hate relationship.Love it for its characters, setting, fantastic soundtrack, bosses and butt-ton of weapons,and hate it for its brutal difficulty and the occasional area where good runs go to die (im looking at you crystal caves).So, lets get into it shall we?Nuclear throne is a roguelike shooter set in a post-apocalyptic world filled with mutants, freaks and everything inbetween. You play as a rhag-tag band of mutants, all filled with character and personality. These mutants dream of placing their mutant butts on the nuclear throne, a myth thats believed by these guys. These mutants are special, because as soon as they die, they get teleported back by these mystical portals popping up across the wasteland.The story is simple, you choose a mutant, and you travel across the many lands filled with a variety of freaks, bandits and  floating ♥♥♥♥ing crystals. In every main area (Badlands, scrapyard Etc) you'll encounter a boss that you must slay in order to go to the sub areas (Not the official name, but something I call them). These are areas that are inbetween the ordinary, 3 level areas. These are 1 level areas that are completely different in setting to other areas and hold special enemies and loot.After doing all of this (Trust me, its a long task) and doing specific things related to things I cant say due to spoilers, you can loop. This means going aaaaaall the way back to the start, but this time its harder, much, much harder. The enemies are tougher and theres a whole new cast of bosses to slay, each one harder than the last. The loot is better, but the risk is bigger.The way collectibles go, there are B-skins for every playable mutant, unlockable by doing specific things, some hard, some are very easy. There are also crowns to unlock through playing, this is essentially run modifiers that you can aquire mid way through the run or at the beginning. They add an extra challenge for the seasoned veteran. There are also golden guns that replace some of the original guns. These special versions are found in a certain area(s) and increase certain stats of the weapon or doing specific things. Also, it shines ingame and can replace the starting pistol if you finish the area its found in.The soundtrack is one of the best ive heard ever. And ive played quite a few games in my time. Each boss has its own song to go in the backround and each area has its own song too. Its so good that I listen to the songs in my spare time.So, to break it down, heres a simpler form of what I just said for the challenged reader:Pros:Fantastic sountrackVibrant characters (That talk in their own made up language)Simple yet enjoyable storyinteresting lore (read that♥♥♥♥♥♥ its brilliant)colourful and marvelously designed areasbeautiful character and enemy designA lot of variety in enemy types and looksBosses are amazing yet challenging if not preparedBrutally hard- Keeps you on your toes at all times, even if you are just fighting a few banditsArtwork is brilliantDevs that listen to the community and are gamers themselvesCons:Some areas are more unbalanced than others (Crystal caves again...)Bugs are uncommon, but come in small sizesOften times you wonder "What the hell just killed me"Thank you for reading, this game is my favorite roguelike, and I love it, even though my hours say otherwise.Would I reccommend this game? Without a doubt. Are there things that could be improved? Of course, but every game is like that. Its 8.99 for endless fun, anger and stupidity with the amount of loot, weapons and collectables to be collected.Thank you again for reading.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing. It's rare that I ever put as much time into a game as I have with this one, and I'm not even close to considering stopping yet. The combat is rarely an issue, and every level provides a new type of challenge to overcome. 12 different characters are featured, each with their own unique passive and active, and all offering a different play style. While some mutations may be better than others, it's impossible to go wrong with mutation choices as they all offer a worthwhile upgrade. All of this combined into an endless roguelike with countless different weapons makes for an amazing experience...If you're patient. The flip side to this game is that it is BRUTALLY difficult. To master this game, unless you're one of those people who's just amazing at video games, you will need time. A lot of it. You will die hundreds, if not thousands of times to mistakes you can't believe you made. I'm approaching 200 hours in this game and I still have rage-inducing deaths on the scrapyard in daily runs.All in all, buy this game! But do so knowing that it will be frustrating and time-consuming to master.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												This is an isometric twin stick rouge-like shooter. You pick you character and off you go. Like many similar games environments are semi-random. You follow themes, enemies and weapons in tiers as you go but each map, amount of enemies their composition (not counting bosses) are all random. This can lead to unfortunate game over by spawning into a car (that has been patched) or in a room where you have no feasible way to get to cover or win, but hey it's a part of it. Just as getting an over powered weapon and steamrolling the opposition.With minimal amount of unlocks the draw of this game is to just be able to hop in, try your best and you are done at the end. Next time you start at the same spot but you are not likely to have the same experience. With hundred or weapons pickups, and numerous powerups to plan your run this game won't go stale any time soon. While you can get unlucky with spawns, the difficulty in this game lies solely on the player. Your decisions, both short term combat tactics as well as long term with choosing right tools for the job as you go and picking the proper or most suitable mutations. It makes it so when you die,  nine times out of ten it's on you. Always room for improvement. The game has no 'real' end. After you complete the stages you loop it with harder enemies and more new weapons.Guns are really the star of this game. It goes from the basic screwdriver and revolver to absurdity of super plasma cannon or nuke launcher. You will redecorate the level with some of these. It is really satisfying plowing through things with laser minigun or blowing up the area with super bazooka or so. The farther you get the more reward you can reap with better and more over the top toys. If you are the kind of person where the feel of combat, shooting (or swinging) makes or breaks the game for you. This fits the bill.Overall I'd add this to the list of outstanding rouge-likes that are easy to pick up, put down and be satisfied with every turn.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Nuclear Throne.A rogue-like twin stick shooter created by Vlambeer, a company with an excellent track record, no doubt about that.I saw this and bought it immediately: roguelikes, a bit of bullet hell, and a badass illuminati character all drew me in.I was not dissapointed.Characters--each with their own story, with their own abilities, with their own personal mutations that go with them.Weapons--too many to count; whenever i pick up a weapon I've never see before, it's like an new game to me.Enemies--each with bizzare weapons and attacks, and the bosses are intimidating and a thrill to play against.Music--amazing soundtrack, adds to the game's theme of "A nuclear fallout with absurd creatures and guns everywhere"Secrets--do I really need to go into these? A plethora of secrets, and when you find them, well; I'll leave that to you.However, I haven't tried co-op, and only have 10 hours on it, so I don't know everything about the game. About half the negative reviews complain that the game is too hard and are only open for a small amount of gamers.I do acknowledge this fact, and warn you if you're buying it that there will be runs cut off by a bad spawn.But you are getting more than your money's worth in terms of gameplay. Heavily, HEAVILY consider this as a potential roguelike to purchase. From my experience, Nuclear Throne is an absolute blast.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Vlambeer is one of my favorite indie developers for several reasons.  I've seen the devs quite a bit in various videogame documentaries and so to some small extent I feel like I know them.  A consist level of quality, along with their unique retro-style, can be found across their various titles.  Its in the aesthetics that there games really shine, from the beautiful art to the superb sound design.  Yet, as much as I like the studio for some reason I have yet to really fall in love with any of their games.  This is not to say Nuclear Throne is bad by any means but there just isn't quite enough there to keep me coming back.So from what I understand this game takes place after a nuclear fallout and the mutated creatures that spawned from the event are competing with each other to be the best in order to eventually reach the illustrious heights of the Nuclear Throne.  That is all the story you're getting because this game is clearly focused on gameplay.  In Nuclear Throne you're simply dropped into a room where you have to kill all the enemies.  Once thats done you're sucked into a warp hole where you'll teleport to the next level where you'll do the exact same thing.  As you progress you'll be rewarded experience and every time you level up you'll get to choose between four random upgrades to aid you in the increasing challenging battles.As you can imagine, with such a simple concept there must be a variety in the means of which you clear these rooms.  There is a handful playable characters each with a unique special power and passive trait.  Thankfully, you'll find a good selection of weapons as you fighting for your life.  There are five different ammo types including bullets, shells, bolts, etc which leads you find different kinds of machine guns, crossbows, shotguns, and so on.  For the most part they all feel quite good and its easy to quickly find your preferences.  This is an intense, fast-paced game, and you'll need to be able to adapt quickly as the enemies will be shooting right back at you.  With the cross-hairs a fair distance from your character aiming can be quite a challenge in itself.Its the visuals and sound effects that really make this game worthwhile.  The guns in this game sound like they really got some nice kick to them.  All the playable characters and enemies look great.  There is a lot of charm in the theme of this game.  This is really important because the gameplay can get quite repetitive.  Even though the maps are procedurally generated you're basically always stuck fighting in fairly cramped arenas.  Every two or three levels you will face a different group of enemies but after you've played several times the battles tend to all feel pretty similar.  That being said you'll always being on the edge of your seat trying to make every shot count while at the same time trying to avoid the onslaught of enemy fire.The fact is this is a simple shoot-em up.  There is nothing wrong with that if thats what you're in to just don't expect much more.  Since this is such a though game the hope is that you'll keep learning as play and just get a little bit farther after each attempt.  Since this is a rogue-like once you die thats it, you have to start right at the beginning and there is nothing to carry over from one run to the next.  This is a game the requires a lot of dedication for mastery.  Although I personally don't have the patience to get really good I did have fun while playing this game.  I would only recommend it to those who really think they're up for a challenge.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												One of the best games of all time! I have not had this much fun with any game since I was a yung lil rat. This game is easily within my top five games ever made.Pros:-Highly addictive-Great controls-Wide variety of gameplay styles (a lot of replayability)-Rewarding unlocks-Great pacing-Great artwork and music-Menus and loading are quicker than 2.998x10^10 m/s (the retry button in this game is similar to how quick respawning in Super Meat Boy is)Cons:-Sometimes the randomized elements can make the game frustrating, because it feels like the odds are pitted against you-There does seem to be a considerable learning curve, but for some people this is a good thing (myself included). Usually most players do not have a complaint with this fact and it just adds to the fun, but I felt it should be mentioned.

All the different characters have very different abilities and each one makes you change your tatics, not to mention the killer soundtrack and satifying SFX for the guns and the hit impact. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23
												A few years ago, I found myself wishing for a game where I could just gun down hordes of enemies and feel really overpowered. Then, a short while later, I found Nuclear Throne. This game is a crazy fun top-down rogue-like shooter thingy, and I love it to death.I love everything about this game. When first playing it, it's challenging, but has a satisfying learning curve to it. Getting farther and farther, finding new, creative weapons, unlocking new characters to play, and just having that feeling of "one more run, and I can make it further than before" was such a great time. Over time, old obstacles become easy, and you find yourself getting far every time and having crazy runs that are fun as hell. But the game stays challenging no matter how good you get at it. Even after mastering the game and unlocking almost everything, the game still poses a challenge, just in a different sense than when first starting out. The most exhilarating part of it all is that while you may have crazy overpowered weapons, you're still as frail, if not more frail, then any single enemy you fight. All it takes is a few mistakes and you're done. But dying isn't an issue, all you gotta do is hit the R key and jump back into it, and within ten minutes you could already be as far as you were when you died. Once you get on a crazy run, it's just an adrenaline rush of gunning down hordes of enemies while constantly having to keep on your toes to make sure you don't end up dead. And when you inevitably wind up dead, you can take a breather as you fight your way through the early levels on your way to another crazy run.Another amazing thing about this game I have to note is the sound. Everything in this game sounds... Satisfying. Picking up weapons, switching between them, shooting things, killing enemies; everything has a satisfying punch to it. Every enemy has a unique sound for getting hit, and for dying, so even if you're shooting at things off-screen, you still know what you're hitting and whether or not you killed them. The soundtrack is amazing, too, to the point where I sometimes listen to the songs outside of the game. The game's also got a lot of character to it. Every mutant you can play as is unique and has their own lore behind them. The universe is very interesting, and all the details about it are shown rather than told, for the most part. You learn about the world through the little details in the game, and it all adds up and is very interesting. Deep lore n' stuff. Of course, you can ignore the lore and just enjoy the crazy fun shooting parts, too.Overall, the best word to describe this game for me is "satisfying." It's satisfying to kill things, satisfying to reach further and further levels than your previous best, satisfying to find and master the tons of crazy weapons in the game, satisfying when something blows up and the screen freezes for a split second to add to the punch. I've played this game constantly for over two years now, and it's still kept me satisfied after all this time. The best part is that this game was and still is very affordable in terms of price, and is totally worth it. I recommend this game heavily to nearly everyone I meet.I've been regularly playing this game since December of 2014, and I don't plan on stopping anytime soon. Seriously, pick it up and give it a try, it's amazing.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game takes a while to get used to. IF you are a fan of top down shooters this is your type of game. Basically all you have to do is kill enemies and survive. That's pretty much it. You get 10 characters to play with most of them you'll unlock in an hour. Also this game is about stratagy, you gotta pick the right weapons, and attack at the right time. Now what I'm saying is, is that it's like a bullet hell sometimes but you can walk in all directions. Melee is your best bet if you want to stop/deflect bullets. Guns are just guns, crossbows are your nice weapons, and explosives make sure you have  some distance or you might die. And that's pretty much it. I highly recommend this for medium level gamers, this is not an easy game to play. 10/10Good graphics.Good amount of characters.Great soundtrack.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Nuclear Throne has made elegant strides through its early access stage into production.  It is the epitome of a nu-rogue.  Each character's special abilities are vastly different, and it is a joy to play any of them.  In fact, I find myself picking random as my character to have that mysery in which play style I will use that run; it  adds to the rogue-ness.  The gun firing controls are as tight as Kim Kardashian's spandex.  If you die, it is your fault even if you feel brutally defeated.  This game is as hard as a diamond nipple ring in Antarctica.Getting better and getting to higher levels consistently feeels great, the progression is well done.  This goes for the character unlock incentives, learing all the mutations, and the setting of each section of this nucler wasteland.The Nuclear Throne truly radiates.If you are a fan of dual stick shooters or nu-roguelikes, you are failing yourself by not buying this game.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								I would highly recommend Nuclear Throne to anyone who enjoys a fast paced game. You can start and be dead within a few minutes and you'll start again hungry for more. It is an immensely enjoyable game which is never quite the same any two play throughs, though the bosses will be the same when you come across them. The game is challenging and pushes you to succeed and doesn't hold your hand, added to this is the evolution system with gaining levels, you can change in a number of ways, from carrying more ammo, to having homing missiles for crossbow bolts, they are all exciting to pick and change the gameplay in their own manner.Added to the fun gameplay there is a wide choice of characters to pick from, each with their own personality and way of playing, this helps the longevity of the game as jumping from Steroids to the Rebel is a vast change in how to approach the combat.I am a solid fan of the game and give it a personal 8/10

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have just started playing this game after it being recommended to me by a friend, and I thought I might mention a few of the pros and cons of this game so far. Baring in mind this is early access the cons are what I recommend for the final game and should be added in for a better experience.Pros:-8 Bit Graphics are cool, keep it that way. Fits the play style perfectly.-A gradual difficulty slope that is easy enough for you to progress but difficult enought to make you want to come back for more, but I found that a few people (not including myself) found that it was more difficult than expected. -Plenty of stages and levels to progress through, but it would be nice if you were to add more as people get better at it.-Charatcers: the variety is great and all the special abilities and mutations means each run is unique and different from the last. It would be nice to see more for those who have played with every character and need something new.-No micro-transactions at this time, baring in my it is still early access there is know means of putting money into the game after you have bought it, this is good!Cons:-Not full screen, The game runs in full screen but you have black bars along the side, please remove it as it is an ugly feature and the game would look cleaner and more atractive in a widescreen view. Though this isn't the end of the world it would be nice if the game had some graphics settings.-30 FPS Cap!! What? Why? I am not sure exactly why the game devs have made it so the game can only be run at 30fps or less. Surely if the PC can run it higher (which almost any pc can) it should be allowed. This made the game feel ever so slightly choppy but it was fine overall.-Co-op can only be done in a local network. Sadly this means I can not play with friends unless I bring my pc into the same internet as theirs or play split screen with a controller. Make a means of playing co-op online with people on steam. This would make the game more tactical as you would have to work together. I think this would be a great addition for the final game. Summary:Should you buy this game?Yes, if you need some time to kill and are willing to pack in a few hours learning the characters and improving. It is worth the price especially as they have updated it over 90 times since the original release. This game has perma-death so expect to get annoyed throughout the time of playing it. Anyway I hope this review helped you make a more informed decision on wether this game is for you. Leave a like if it did, Thanks.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Dutch two-man studio Vlambeer has made a name for itself by producing quirky, high-energy boutique games like Super Crate Box, Radical Fishing and Luftrauser. Their newest experiment, Nuclear Throne, expands upon a Mojam prototype the group produced in early 2013, called Wasteland Kings.You start by picking a mutant from a menagerie of interesting characters, like a fishman that can dodge roll, a chicken with a katana and bullet-time, a Little Shop of Horrors style plant that snares enemies, or a crystal dude that can reflect enemy bullets. Level layouts are randomly generated and populated, making each short play session unique. There’s incredibly strong feedback on your actions, giving the whole thing that unique punch and crunch  Vlambeer is known for. Death comes quick: enemies are relentless, health pickups are rare.As you progress, you’re given the option to mutate your character, improving them in some way, from a handful of randomly-chosen options. Right now, nothing is permanent in Nuclear Throne. Every time you start, it’s from scratch, keeping in line with the “Roguelike-like” ethos the team is going for. Vlambeer admits, “We have no clue where we’re going to end up on this project and that’s really fine with us.” You can buy the Early Access version on Steam right now, with Mac, PS4 and Vita versions planned for much later.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Incredibly fun and unforgiving.  You start the game out with a revolver and some bullets and work through randomly generated levels trying to manage your health and ammo while collecting pieces of radiation from the corpses of your fallen enemies and canisters that are placed on the map.  Collecting enough will eventualy allpw you to level up....but only once you beat the current level.  Once you beat the level, youll be given several randomly generated "mutations" or perks to choose from that do various things like modfy your special ability, give you more health, increase your ammo cap, increase drop rates, allow you to pick up items from further away, or countless others.  There are clear mutations that are better for certain characters and some that are just good choices overall. This game shines in comparisn to other rougelike games in its ability for you to cater a run and have the objectives to be to try and get x or y weapon and get a, b, and c mutations.  Unlike in games like th binng of issac where you will just get random weapons and there are too many for you to be able to realiably make a plan, there are enough to provide variety while not being so much that its overwhelming to understand and providing enough oppertunitie to switch weapons on levels.  Its also really important to understand that while you can "plan" your runs to do something in particular, it is still hard to execute because you have to stay on your feet the entire time and one stray bullet, misfired rocket, or graze against the wrong enemy is enough to end even the most promsing of runs.  While nuclear thorne is still in early access, the game has more going for it than many games that are already published in the same price range.  Unlike other games with different playable classes and  characters, there is no clearly best character and every character has their own unique playstyle that can be played effectively.  The game has constantly been recieving updates and Im looking forward to even more in the future!

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								If there was a "no reccomendation" button, I would click it. In Nuclear Throne, you play as one of many mutants trying to reach, as you may have guessed, the Nuclear Throne. You do not complete the game, you see how far you can get (once you "pass" the nuclear throne, you loop over from level one- except it's way harder). It's a fun game full of guns, explosions, and plentiful enemies to make you want to throw your computer at your tv in pure frustration.However, the one awful flaw (an awflaw?) I've been experiencing are the spawn points. I believe you have seven dimensions, and you have three levels in each dimention. The third level always has a boss. So they made the level almost like an arena- NO SAFE ZONES. This often leaves you spawning right smack in the middle of the stage. And in the scrapyard where there are literally aimbot snipers (they're robots), it's not fun to spawn with five crosshairs looking at you.Game over.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												After 50 hours with Nuclear Throne I can say with confidence it is worth the purchase. Also, I can say with confidence that I am terrible at it. This game is a bullethell-rouguelike-topdown-twinstick shooter, and it is quite good. The art is nice, and each character is balanced, although each player will end up having a favorite. The gameplay is fast. Really fast. As soon as I die I am left pondering what killed me (thankfully it tells you). You will definitely learn to react quicker and the strategies required to loop throughout your playtime with this game. Daily challenges and weekly challenges keep me coming back, and I love to participate in them. Seeing how I stack up against friends is really fun and I love seeing where I place worldwide (someday I'll be in the top 100 I swear). For the price, it is definitely worth the purchase (also the music is fantastic).

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Roguelikes have to be my favorite kind of game, and Nuclear Throne happens to be masterfully made to be a nearly perfect roguelike. I've played my fair share of roguelikes, more than what my Steam profile may tell you, and I have to say this is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ near the best one. In the aspect of gameplay and intensity, this is certainly the highest ranking roguelike in my opinion, yet I find myself playing more Binding of Isaac sheerly because there's no way to tell what kind of crazy stuff will happen next. Nuclear Throne is more of a straightforward roguelike, there aren't many "crazy" things that can happen except for a few secrets that you might accidentally encounter, but it still stands to be intense and engaging in its gameplay. Another thing to mention is that most roguelikes have some kind of ending to the game, yet this does not. Sure, it may have a "final" boss, but the game still progresses afterwards and greets you with a few more new bosses on top of stronger incantations of older bosses. The fact that this game never ends, just keeps going and going for as long as you can survive, makes it kind of feel arcade-style, and it makes you want to keep practicing to keep going. So where Nuclear Throne doesn't have as much of a randomness aspect as The Binding of Isaac, it makes up for it by constantly challenging you, no matter how good you are at the game.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								A lot of people call Nuclear Throne a roguelike. This is a dumb thing to call it because a) all useful meaning has long been wrung from the term and b) we already have a word for games like this. Nuclear Throne is an ARCADE GAME. It is loud and bright and deceptively simple and when you die you start over from the beginning. Nuclear Throne is a throwback so pure it should come with a USB-compatible coin slot so that I can stop playing when I run out of quarters instead of never. I could also use a lot of vogue words like “tactile” and “crunchy” to describe how Nuclear Throne plays, but I’d rather just play it instead. Jargon like this gets thrown around when our normal vocabulary falls short of describing an experience. In response we can either pore over the dictionary or enjoy the fuzzy space between word and meaning. Intellectualizing ♥♥♥♥ing Defender doesn’t get you the high score.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: The Binding of Isaac + pixel graphics + guns + a bit of bullet hell = Nuclear Throne. Tons of fun and replayablility, even in the early access stage. Has more fun in such a small, cheap package than a lot of $60 titles have to offer. Buy it. ALSO IF YOU CAN'T HAVE FUN SHOOTING THINGS WITH A GATTLING BAZOOKA THEN YOU NEED TO REEVALUATE YOUR LIFE.EDIT:I've put enough hours into this game that I feel like I can review this game in it's current state pretty thoroughly.Gameplay-Rouge-like, procedurally generated, difficult, and extremely satisfying. The crunch is real. Tons of weapons, mutations, and characters that all synergize in different ways pretty well. More mutations will be added as well as weapons (characters too? I dunno.) and that makes me pretty damn excited. As of right now, there's a few mutations that are absolutely necessary for a good run (I'm looking at you, back muscle), so there are a few balancing things that'll be tweaked. In any case, it's not horribly unbalanced by any means. If anything, it's pretty well-balanced. And a TON of fun and replay value.Music-YES. WONDERFUL. GREAT. CRUNCHY.Story-Hah. Yeah okay. You're going to kill a bunch of things through a bunch of procedurally-generated levels to kill a big radiation-infested chair. This isn't a story-driven game. It's all about the gameplay.What I liked-IT'S SO CRUNCHY.What I hated-"WHAAAT. THAT KILLED ME???? Okay, let's try again."My personal recommendation: $13 IS A STEAL FOR THIS GAME. You'll get WAY more than $13 out of this title if you like rouge-like games. Even if you don't like rouge-like games (or don't know what they are), I'd still pick this one up. It's just a blast.I can't give this a score out of 10 because it's not finished, but as it stands right now, I'm thinking about a 9 out of 10.
